LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Islamic Republic of Pakistan (Pakistan) 
   
The Proposal  This proposal comprises a loan of $75 million from the ordinary capital 
resources  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  a  loan  of 
$75 million  equivalent  from  ADB's  Special  Funds  resources  for 
subprogram  2  of  the  Punjab  Government  Efficiency  Improvement 
Program (PGEIP). 
 
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention. 
Sector (subsector): Public sector management (economic and public 
affairs management, public expenditure and fiscal management, 
education sector development, health finance). 
Themes (subthemes): Governance (public administration), private 
sector development (policy reforms), economic growth (promoting 
economic efficiency and enabling business environment), capacity 
development (institutional development). 
Location impact: National (high impact). 
   
Environment  Category C       
Assessment 
   
Program Rationale  Punjab  is  the  largest  provincial  economy  and  the  most  populous 
province of Pakistan, accounting for more than 50% of the country's 
gross domestic product and population. Punjab has achieved robust 
economic  growth  and  significant  poverty  reduction  in  recent  years. 
However, it still faces numerous development challenges arising from 
the low standard of living and the high incidence of poverty. Average 
per capita income in the province is only about $1,000. The poverty 
ratio remains high at over 20%. The level of well-being measured by 
social indicators is also low. Punjab's infrastructure is underdeveloped. 
There is an acute power shortage, and 90% of the provincial road 
network is rated as fair to poor. Punjab lacks sufficient employment 
opportunities. Each year nearly 1.6 million youths enter the labor force. 
The official unemployment rate of 8% reflects prevalent underreporting.  
 
  Addressing  Punjab's  challenges  requires  the  province  to  maintain 
inclusive growth at 7%–8% per annum. Yet, long-term economic growth 
since the 1970s has been only about 5%. Inclusive growth requires the 
provision of infrastructure and social services to enable the poor and 
vulnerable, including women, to participate in development.   
 
  The Government of Punjab (the government) has made accelerating 
income  growth  and  improving  social  services  its  twin  development 
objectives. Punjab’s Vision 2020 envisages the doubling of per capita 
income to about $2,000 by 2020 and significantly improving service 
delivery. The government has identified an efficient, accountable, and 
capable public sector and a dynamic private sector as the institutional 
foundations for achieving these objectives. These factors underpin the 
design of the PGEIP.

ii   
 
   
Program  The  PGEIP  is  a  program  cluster  comprising  three  single-tranche 
Description  subprograms. The proposed subprogram 2 builds upon and expands 
the subprogram 1 reform agenda. The subprogram 2 supports reforms 
in five key policy areas:  
 
(i)  public  financial  management:  the  adoption  of  output-based 
budgets that link expenditures to service delivery;  
(ii)  contingent  liability  management:  partly  funding  pension  and 
General Provident (GP) Fund liabilities;  
(iii)  civil  service  management:  linking  performance  with  service 
delivery indicators, as well as private sector development; 
(iv)  promoting  public–private  partnership  (PPP)  for  infrastructure 
and  social  service  delivery;  especially  education  and  health 
services; and 
(v)  results-based  management  (RBM):  promoting  greater 
accountability for results in public sector management.  
The RBM is a new core policy area introduced in subprogram 2 drawing 
on lessons learned in the first subprogram. The PGEIP will help the 
government achieve high, sustained, and private sector–driven growth 
and improved service delivery. The outcome of subprogram 2 is greater 
government efficiency, accountability, and capability. 
 
Financing Plan  Two loans are proposed for subprogram 2:   
 
(i)  A  loan  of  $75  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources 
under the London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending 
facility. The loan will have a 15-year term, including a grace 
period  of  3  years;  an  interest  rate  to  be  determined  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility;  a 
commitment charge of 0.15% per annum; and such other terms 
and conditions as set forth in the draft loan agreement.  
(i)  A  loan  of  $75  million  equivalent  from  ADB’s  Special  Fund 
resources, with an interest rate of 1% per annum during the 
grace  period  and  1.5%  per  annum  thereafter;  a  term  of  24 
years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms 
and conditions as set forth in the draft loan agreement. 
 
Pakistan will be the borrower. The Government of Pakistan will relend 
the local currency generated from the loan proceeds to the Government 
of  Punjab.  The  terms  and  conditions  will  be  the  same  as  those 
extended by ADB to Pakistan. The Government of Punjab will assume 
foreign exchange and interest rate risks.   
 
The government has requested $250 million for subprograms 2 and 3 
as envisaged in the preparation of the program cluster. The loan size 
and composition for subprogram 3 will be confirmed during processing 
on the bases of reform progress, requirements, and the availability of 
resources.

iii
Counterpart Funds  The government will ensure that the local currency generated from the 
proceeds of the loans will be used, first, to support the adjustment costs 
of reforms to be initiated and implemented under subprogram 2 and, 
second,  to  finance  expenditures  for  the  government’s  general 
development purposes.  
   
Program Period and  The implementation period of PGEIP is from July 2006 to around March 
Tranching  2011.  Subprogram  2  covers  reform  measures  implemented  from 
January 2008 to September 2009. The loans are single tranche loans to 
be disbursed upon satisfaction of policy actions under subprogram 2 
and following loan effectiveness. The proposal for subprogram 3 will be 
submitted  for  Board  consideration  about  18–20  months  after  loan 
effectiveness for subprogram 2, subject to the government’s readiness 
to continue with its reform agenda.  
   
Executing Agency   The  Planning  and  Development  Department  of  the  Government  of 
Punjab will be the Executing Agency.  
   
Implementation  Subprogram  2  uses  the  same  implementation  arrangements  as 
Arrangements  subprogram  1.  A  senior  steering  committee  chaired  by  the  chief 
secretary of the government and comprising members from the public 
and  private  sectors  guides  program  implementation.  An  executive 
committee under the planning and development chairman oversees and 
ensures efficient program implementation. The program management 
unit coordinates program implementation. 
 
Procurement and  The loan proceeds will finance the foreign exchange costs (excluding 
Disbursement  local duties and taxes) of items produced in and procured from ADB 
member countries, excluding ineligible items and imports financed from 
other bilateral and multilateral sources. ADB will have the right to audit 
the use of the loan proceeds and verify the accuracy of the Borrower’s 
certification. Loan proceeds will be disbursed to the Borrower according 
to  ADB’s  Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related 
Requirements for Program Loans (1998).  
   
Program Benefits  The PGEIP is expected to yield the following benefits for the residents 
and Beneficiaries  of Punjab.   
 
More efficient use of public financial resources. The shift from input- 
to output-based budgets will strengthen efficiency and accountability in 
the use of public resources. The rationalization of many underfunded 
projects will increase the efficiency of public investment.  
 
Improved  financial  sustainability  for  the  pension  system.  The 
partial prefunding of the pension and GP Fund will improve system 
sustainability, alleviate the pension outlay on the current budget, and 
reduce  contingent  liabilities.  It  will  promote  savings  and  asset 
accumulation, which will contribute to growth. Better record-keeping will 
reduce leakages and improve accountability.

iv   
 
An efficient, accountable, and capable civil service. More efficient 
institutional  structures,  simpler  business  procedures,  better  human 
resource management, and improved capacity in the public sector will 
improve the performance of the government.   
 
A dynamic private sector. The establishment of policy and institutional 
frameworks for PPP will enable Punjab to benefit from both public and 
private resources, resulting in more and better infrastructure and social 
service delivery.      
 
Greater focus on accountability. The adoption of RBM will transform 
public sector management from micro control to a greater focus on 
results. This combination of accountability for results and flexibility for 
management is the hallmark of modern public sector management and 
will modernize government operations in Punjab.  
 
Gender  benefits.  Punjab's  result  framework  explicitly  spells  out 
government  targets  on  gender  equity,  particularly  in  health  and 
education. The subprogram 2 has helped to identify large funding gaps 
and  increased  budget  allocation  in  the  health  sector,  with  positive 
benefits to woman and children through increased access to medicine 
and improved medical facilities. The budgeting and planning processes 
in Punjab are paying increased attention to gender equity in budget 
allocations. Institutions that are tasked to work on gender equity, such 
as the Directorate of Women’s Development, have been set up to carry 
out the gender reform action plan.    
 
All  the  benefits  will  contribute  to  employment  creation,  inclusive 
economic growth, and improved service delivery.   
   
Assumption, Risks,  Major risks are summarized below.  
and Safeguards   
Security risks. The number of violent assaults has increased in recent 
months in Pakistan, and the frequency of such incidents has increased 
in Punjab. The Government of Pakistan is implementing measures to 
contain security risks. Sustained economic growth and stability are key 
to achieving peace and prosperity in the country.   
 
Political risks. Political tension, compounded by justice sector issues, 
resulted in March 2009 in the dismissal of an elected government in 
Punjab,  which  was  subsequently  reinstated.  Recent  developments 
indicate a more cooperative approach between major political parties. 
The risk of reversing the directions of program reforms is low given the 
broad consensus on reforms.   
 
Macroeconomic risks. The Government of Pakistan has launched a 
stabilization  program  to  improve  the  macroeconomic  situation  and 
restore investor confidence. ADB is a major partner through its support 
under  the  Accelerating  Economic  Transformation  Program,  which 
provides measures to deal with short-term shocks and address long-
term  structural  issues.  PGEIP  measures  to  tackle  institutional  and 
policy impediments to growth in Punjab will help to reduce economic 
vulnerability in the medium term.

v
 
Weak capacity. With the help of a technical assistance loan and grant, 
the  program  management  unit  and  departments  involved  are 
addressing  capacity  limitations.  Enhancing  implementing  agency 
ownership of the PGEIP has helped to mitigate implementation risks.  
 
Intergovernmental coordination. The civil service reform component 
of subprogram 2 requires effective intergovernmental coordination. The 
upfront work being done on civil service reforms has been disseminated 
widely. Change management, including stakeholder consultation and 
communication, forms an important part of program implementation to 
lessen resistance and increase support for reforms.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on two proposed 
loans to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the second subprogram of the Punjab Government 
Efficiency Improvement Program (PGEIP).1    
 
II.  MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
2.  Pakistan. Real gross domestic product (GDP) expanded 7% annually on average from 
fiscal year (FY) 2002 to FY2008. Per capita income doubled to about $1,000, and the poverty 
incidence reduced significantly over this period.2 Economic conditions have worsened since late 
FY2008,  however,  amid  rising  world  oil  and food  prices,  global  financial  turmoil,  domestic 
political instability, and the deteriorating security situation. Growth slowed from 7.5% in FY2007 
to 5.8% in FY2008 and is expected to be 3.4% in FY2009. The fiscal deficit rose to 7.4% and 
the current account deficit widened to 8.4% of GDP in FY2008, and inflation reached 25% in 
October 2008. A serious debt overhang in the power sector has aggravated the already acute 
power shortage and seriously disrupted economic activity and investment.   
 
3.  Against  this  background,  the  Government  of  Pakistan  launched  its  Economic 
Stabilization Program and entered into a 23-month stand-by arrangement with the International 
Monetary Fund in November 2008. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been a key partner 
in stabilization efforts, with a focus on social safety nets and structural reforms in energy and 
finance through the Accelerating Economic Transformation Program.3 Signs of recovery have 
emerged as fiscal and current account deficits declined, the exchange rate stabilized, and 
inflation abated, though macroeconomic conditions are still vulnerable.  
 
4.  Punjab. Punjab is the largest provincial economy of Pakistan. Its provincial GDP is 
estimated at about $72 billion, or 50% of the national total. It is also the most populous province, 
with 87 million inhabitants, or 56% of the country’s population. The economic performance of 
Punjab plays a critical role in the overall economic strength of Pakistan. 
 
5.  Punjab has achieved robust economic performance in recent years. Between FY2002 
and FY2007, growth averaged over 7%, GDP per capita doubled, the poverty head-count ratio 
declined by about 11 percentage points to 20%, and key social indicators significantly improved. 
However, economic conditions have deteriorated since late 2007, as in the rest of the country. 
The revised estimate for the FY2009 budget deficit is PRs95.8 billion, triple that of the previous 
year and the original estimate (see Supplementary Appendix A). Federal fiscal transfers account 
for about 80% of provincial revenue. Any shortfall in transfers reduces the ability of the province 
to pursue its own development objectives.

2005 estimated that poverty declined from 34.5% in FY2002 to 23.9% in FY2006, the World Bank estimated that 
poverty incidence declined from 34.5% to 29.2% over the same period. Either estimate represents a significant 
reduction in poverty. Government of Pakistan, Federal Bureau of Statistics. 2006. Pakistan Social and Living

2   
III.  THE SECTOR 
A.  Long-Term Economic Performance and Development Challenges 
6.  Punjab faces a number of interlinked development challenges, chief among them the low 
standard of living and the high poverty incidence. Average per capita income in Punjab is about 
$1,000,  which  is  only  two-thirds  of  the  average  of  low  middle  income  countries.  Income 
inequality is high. Poverty incidence remained over 20% in 20074, the most recent year for 
which data are available, and is likely to have increased since then with the economic slowdown.    
 
7.  Social indicators are poor in Punjab. Over one-third of children under the age of 5 are 
underweight. The infant mortality rate of 71 per 1,000, and the maternal mortality rate of 300 per 
100,000 are double the Millennium Development Goal (MDG) targets. The literacy rate for 
children 10 years of age and above is only 56%. Nearly 9.6 million children of school-going age, 
or 30%, are out of school. Only half of the population is served by piped water systems. There 
are  large  gender,  income,  and  rural–urban  inequalities.  Gender  disparity  is  particularly 
pronounced. The female literacy rate for age 15 and above is 35.2%, about half that of men. 
Underemployment is 45% for women, compared to 8% for men. The estimated earned income 
for females is only about one-third of that for males.   
 
8.  Punjab's infrastructure is underdeveloped. An acute power crisis brings frequent outages. 
A survey of 650 firms noted that 80% of firms complained that the most important deterrent to 
investing was power shortages.5 About 90% of the provincial road network is rated as fair to 
poor.  Poor  urban  infrastructure  impairs  the  competitiveness  of  Punjab  cities,  affects  the 
environment and health conditions, and dampens investment.    
 
9.  Employment is the most direct route for income generation. As of June 2007, Punjab's 
labor  force  stood  at  50.3  million.  The  official  unemployment  rate  of  8%  reflects  prevalent 
underreporting. The labor force grew at an annual rate of 3.2%, and nearly 1.6 million youths 
enter the labor force each year. Lack of productive employment opportunities is a serious 
problem. Further, 74% of nonagricultural employed labor in Punjab is in the informal sector, and 
the share for female workers in informal employment is even higher.    
 
10.  Addressing Punjab's development challenges will not be possible without rapid and 
sustained economic growth. However, the long-term growth rate of Punjab since the 1970s has 
been about 5.1%, falling short of the desired rate of 7%–8% per annum. Punjab's growth should 
be inclusive. This requires the provision of infrastructure and social services to enable the poor 
and vulnerable, including women, to participate in economic development.   
 
B.  Issues and Opportunities  
11.  A  key  problem  leading  to  the  challenges  in  Punjab  is  the  poor  quality  of  public 
institutions and lack of accountability for results. A problem tree summarizing this development 
problem and its major causes and effects is presented in Figure 1. More details on issues and 
opportunities are in Appendix 2.

4   
 
1.  Need for Better Mobilization and Utilization of Public Financial Resources 
12.  Background. Budgeting in Punjab follows a dual system. The Finance Department 
prepares and manages the recurrent budget, and P&DD manages the development budget. 
Recurrent budget estimates are based on historical trends, with yearly increments to cover 
additional costs. Thus, budgeting in Punjab is input-based and incremental.  
 
13.  Incomplete  medium-term  budgetary  framework  (MTBF)  implementation.  The 
incremental and input-oriented approach to budgeting suffers multiple weaknesses. The lack of 
reliable estimates and enforcement of the resource envelope for the province or of strategic 
allocation for each sector leads to poor budget allocation, especially for development plans, 
which remain severely underfunded. Budget outturns for expenditures deviate significantly from 
budget allocations. Line departments often require supplementary grants during the fiscal year. 
Budget allocations do not adequately reflect service delivery goals and priorities. The allocations 
for key expenditure components, development, non-salary recurrent, and recurrent expenditures 
are often out of sync with one another. There has been chronic under-allocation for non-salary 
recurrent expenditure, such as operation and maintenance (O&M) and medicine expenditures in 
the health sector. This mismatch causes waste and poor service delivery.      
 
14.  The  adoption  of  the  MTBF  will  improve  the  efficiency  and  accountability  of  public 
financial management. The MTBF comprises two major components: (i) a strategic, or top–
down,  element,  and  (ii)  a  bottom–up,  output-based  budgeting  element.  The  top–down 
dimension6 requires the Finance Department to define budget ceilings for each department in 
accordance with the Government of Punjab's (the government) development goals, while the 
bottom–up dimension requires line departments to prioritize and match their expenditures with 
measurable  service  delivery  outputs  within  budget  ceilings.  The  MTBF  thus  provides  a 
structured process through which a department translates its mission into tangible targets in line 
with resource constraints. Supported by subprogram 1, the government adopted the top–down 
dimension of the MTBF for FY2008 to FY2010. However, the bottom–up dimension has not yet 
been introduced.   
 
15.  Continued weak coordination between budgeting and planning. The dual budgeting 
system impedes the integration of budgeting and planning. The Finance Department and P&DD 
follow their own respective calendars and issue separate instructions for formulating the budget 
and development plans. Inconsistencies arise for lack of coherence between the budgeting and 
planning systems, wasting resources. To address the problem, single units were established by 
the Department of Irrigation and Power (DI&P) and the Department of Health (DOH) under 
PGEIP subprogram 1 and the Punjab MDGs Program to oversee the preparation of both the 
current and the development budget. Joint protocols were adopted in 2007 to allow a joint 
review by the Finance Department and P&DD for the two pilot departments. However, these 
mechanisms were yet to be operational at the end of subprogram 1.  
 
16.  Underutilized  development  expenditures.  Punjab's  annual  development  program 
(ADP) for FY2009 was PRs160 billion, accounting for 38% of the budget. While the throw-
forward for the whole ADP has been kept at about 3 years, it varies by sector. In some sectors, 
such as irrigation, the throw-forward can extend to more than 20 years. About 80% of new 
schemes are unapproved, and there are no rules to ensure their speedy approval during the 
                                                 
6 The top–down dimension of the MTBF is also referred to as the medium-term fiscal framework.

5
fiscal year. During midyear reviews of the ADP, funds are reallocated from slow-moving to fast-
moving schemes, but this is subject to P&DD discretion. No rules exist for the prioritization of 
development schemes.   
 
17.  Weak revenue mobilization. Own-source revenue generation is hampered by complex 
tax  structures,  weak  tax  administration  capacity,  and  leakage.  The  Excise  and  Taxation 
Department (E&TD) administers eight taxes, of which the urban immovable property tax (UIPT) 
and the motor vehicles tax (MVT) have the strongest revenue potential. No survey has been 
undertaken for the UIPT since 2001, which results in considerably undervalued property. About 
50% of the UIPT tax base is exempt, amounting to PRs2.4 billion in foregone revenues. MVT 
administration has been inefficient, with incomplete automation of collection. Tax assessment 
and collection are not separated, and there is no effective audit or internal control. This is further 
complicated by tax administration being split between E&TD and the Board of Revenue.  
 
2.  Need for an Affordable and Sustainable Civil Service Pension System 
18.  Background.  With  about  1  million  civil  servants  and  415,000  pensioners,  the 
government is the largest employer in the province. Upon retirement, civil servants are entitled 
to  a  monthly  pension  and  a  lump-sum  General  Provident  Fund  (GP  Fund)  payment.  The 
pension  is  paid  from  the  budget,  while  the  GP  Fund  payment  is  financed  from  monthly 
contributions deducted from civil servants' salaries.    
 
19.  Inadequate financing and reporting of pension and GP Fund costs and liabilities. 
Pension payments have increased at a rate of 12.1% per annum during the last 13 years; and 
are projected to grow by 14% per year in nominal terms over the next 20 years. During the 
preparation of subprogram 1, an actuarial study7 estimated the accrued pension liability at 
PRs425 billion as of 30 June 2007 and the pension expenditure for FY2009 at PRs15.1 billion, 
consuming almost 6% of the recurrent budget. In the case of the GP Fund, the government 
spent PRs3.7 billion in FY2009. GP Fund costs and liabilities have steadily risen due to the 
compounding effect of very high interest payments in the past.  
 
20.  Faced with rising pension and GP Fund costs and liabilities, the government created the 
Punjab Pension Fund (PPF) in March 2007 and adopted a financing strategy to prefinance 
pension costs. The government initially aimed to accumulate PRs100 billion by FY2016, with the 
expectation of meeting approximately 30% of the annual expenditures from investment income. 
The government has not been on track to reach this funding target during the past few years for 
the reasons set forth in para. 57 (see also Supplementary Appendix B). The financing strategy 
needs to be reevaluated using realistic expectations. In addition, a proper accounting and 
reporting system for pension and GP Fund costs needs to be developed to assist management 
and policy planning. 
 
21.  Lack  of  access  to  reliable  and  complete  data.  Record-keeping  and  benefit 
calculations are largely manual and on paper. A computerized system was developed under the 
PIFRA  to  automate  the  accounting  and  auditing  system,  using  the  software  Systems, 
Applications,  and  Products  in  Data  Processing/Third  Generation  (SAP/R3).  The  database 
includes a human resource module that updates records on payroll, pensions, and the GP Fund. 
The pace and accuracy of data entry are low. At the time of the actuarial valuation in May 2009, 
information  on  29%  of  current  employees  was  entered  in  the  SAP/R3  database,  and  no 
                                                 
7  ADB. 2007. Actuarial Valuation of Punjab Government Pension Scheme (prepared by Nauman A. Cheema). 
Manila.

6   
information was entered on pensioners. Thus the information available is insufficient in both 
quantity  and  quality  for  managing  pension  and  GP  Fund  payments.  The  absence  of  a 
comprehensive and up-to-date record-keeping and information management system, combined 
with  weak  financial  analysis  and  accounting  capacity,  causes  inaccuracies  in  pension 
entitlement calculations and individual payments.  
 
3.  Need for a Merit-Based and Accountable Civil Service 
22.  Background. The Punjab public sector employs 11% of all employed workers in the 
province, making it the largest employer in the formal sector. The civil service wage and pension 
bill accounts for 60% of total consolidated recurrent expenditure. The civil service system is 
commonly perceived to be weak and suffering a broad spectrum of problems.    
 
23.  Weak functions, business processes, and human resource management systems. 
Civil service reforms need to result in a clear division of responsibilities between the private and 
public sectors. The responsibilities of the government in owning, managing, and operating 
commercial activities should be reduced. Government procedures in Punjab are considered 
lengthy and cumbersome. The human resource management system of Punjab is ineffective. 
There are few management tools. Promotion is by seniority and rigidly defined by the All 
Pakistan Unified Grades. There is little chance for technical staff to be promoted to senior levels. 
Compensation is fixed8 for each grade, and there is no room for rewarding performance in the 
mainstream system. Compensation is characterized by the prevalence of fringe benefits such as 
housing and cars that, coupled with poor asset management, create an opaque and wasteful 
system. Recruitment is slow, and the process is not rigorous for non-cadre staff. Training plays 
a little role in skill development. This absence of adequate human resource management tools 
has frustrated managers and caused the overuse of administrative orders and frequent staff 
transfers, both of which disrupt performance. For staff, this system provides little motivation to 
perform, grow, or develop in line with organization goals. 
 
4.  Need for Dynamic Private Sector–Led Growth   
24.  Background. Punjab's private sector plays an important role in Pakistan, accounting, for 
example, for over half of the country’s industrial production and about 70% of manufacturing 
establishments. The elasticity of outputs with respect to employment in most industries is above 
1, indicating that a 1% increase in outputs leads to an increase of more than 1% in employment. 
In recent years, Punjab's industrial sector experienced robust growth and generated many new 
employment  opportunities.  Despite  this,  the  business  climate  is  constrained  by  regulatory 
hurdles, low human capital, and poor infrastructure.  
  
25.  Need to remove infrastructure bottlenecks through PPP. Weak infrastructure has 
particularly hindered industrial performance in Punjab. A power crisis causing frequent outages 
undermines business. The unsatisfactory state of the transportation network has imposed large 
costs on the economy. Lack of repair and maintenance has caused rapid deterioration, with 
90% of the provincial network rated as fair to poor. In recent years, PPPs have emerged as a 
major instrument for financing and providing public services, gradually replacing the traditional 
public sector modality. The government has introduced several partnership models. However, 
mainstreaming PPP requires enabling policy and institutional frameworks that are not well 
                                                 
8  This system distinguishes seniority into 22 basic pay scale grades and defines how many years of services are 
required for each grade.

7
developed in the province. There are acute capacity constraints, with very little experience in 
developing PPP projects.   
 
C.  Development Partner Support of Reforms in Punjab 
26.  The  government  fully  recognizes  the  development  challenges  and  issues,  and  has 
identified six pillars of reforms to address ongoing challenges: 
 
(i)  improving  fiscal  and  public  financial  management  and  instituting  a 
results-oriented medium-term planning and budgeting system, 
(ii)  establishing a well-funded and adequate pension system, 
(iii)  fostering an efficient civil service, 
(iv)  promoting private sector–led growth and public–private partnership (PPP),  
(v)  accomplishing the MDGs, and 
(vi)  improving  access  to  justice  to  enhance  legal  and  regulatory  certainty  and 
enforceability in all economic spheres. 
 
27.  The government has established strong development partnerships with the ADB, World 
Bank, and other development agencies to leverage resources, reinforce commitment towards 
reforms,  and  benefit  from  technical  assistance.  Due  to  the  reform  efforts  and  increased 
resources,  Punjab's  economic  and  social  indicators  have  improved.  For  example,  the  net 
enrollment rate in primary school is 57%, up from 44% in 1999. Immunization coverage rose 
from 57% in 2002 to 76% in 2007. Much remains to be done, however. The key reform efforts 
supported by development partners are discussed below.  
 
28.  Development  Partnership  with  ADB.  Prior  to  2007,  ADB  assistance  to  Punjab's 
reforms  focused  on  (i)  public  resource  management  through  the  implementation  of  two 
subprograms  under  the  Punjab  Public  Resource  Management  Program  (PRMP) 9  and 
(ii) support for local governments and service delivery through the Punjab Devolved Social 
Services Program. Punjab has taken part in federally administered ADB programs like the 
Access to Justice Program10 and the Decentralization Support Program.11 These reforms are 
referred to as the first generation reforms.  
 
29.  The government launched in 2007 its second-generation reforms, which identified the six 
pillars of reforms (para.26). Given the need for financing as well as reinforcing the impetus for 
reforms, it sought ADB support for all six pillars. The first four pillars have been supported 
through the PGEIP cluster. As a follow-on to the Punjab Devolved Social Services Program,12 
subprogram 1 of the Punjab MDGs Program13 supports the fifth pillar of reforms and focuses on

service  delivery  in  the  health  sector.  The  government  has  requested  ADB  assistance  in 
improving access to justice.14 ADB is assisting Pakistan through the Accelerating Economic 
Transformation Program and other programs whose benefits flow to provinces, including Punjab.     
 
30.  ADB-funded programs in Punjab reflect the government's medium-term development 
agenda. Imbued with the spirit of inclusive growth, the design of subprogram 2 reflects the five 
strategic drivers of change in ADB’s long-term strategic framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 2020): 
(i) private sector development and private sector operations, (ii) good governance and capacity 
development, (iii) knowledge solutions, (iv) partnerships, and (v) gender equity.15 The PGEIP is 
consistent with the Country Partnership Strategy (2009-2013)16 for Pakistan, which identifies 
governance and institutional bottlenecks as binding constraints on economic growth.   
 
31.  Other Donor Assistance. The World Bank, Department for International Development 
(DFID) of the United Kingdom, and other multilateral and bilateral partners are actively engaged 
in supporting economic and social sector reforms in Punjab. The Project for Improvement in 
Financial Reporting and Auditing (PIFRA), supported by the World Bank, aims to improve the 
accuracy and timeliness of federal, provincial, and district financial reports. The World Bank–
supported Punjab Education Sector Reform Program aims to improve the quality and quantity of 
education available. DFID has supported public financial management, civil service reforms, 
and private sector development under the PRMP umbrella.    
  
32.  Development Partner Coordination. Development partner coordination is supported by 
government-led efforts in the spirit of the Paris Declaration. All development partner assistance 
is channeled through the Planning and Development Department (P&DD) as the nodal agency. 
Because of its critical role in the reforms, the PRMP program management unit (PMU) has been 
assigned the role of donor coordination in governance reforms. This institutionalization of donor 
coordination  has  facilitated  regular  coordination  meetings  with  all  the  partners  involved. 
Appendix 3 provides details on development partner assistance and coordination in Punjab. 
 
D.  Lessons 
33.  Lessons  from  implementing  subprogram  1  and  other  operations  in  Pakistan  are 
summarized below.   
 
34.  Focus on delivering results. Implementation of subprogram 1 highlights that public 
sector management in Punjab is input, activity, and procedure focused; and suffers from a lack 
of  clarity  and  accountability  on  results.  There  are  few  strategic  alignments  between  the 
government's  long-term  vision,  medium-term  strategic  frameworks,  and  annual  budget  and 
human resource management structures.   
 
35.  Reflecting these observations, subprogram 2 includes a new core policy area (CPA) to 
introduce  Results-based  management  (RBM)  to  Punjab.  RBM  is  a  modern  public  sector 
management approach that focuses on achieving development objectives by linking results with 
efficient  public  financial  and  human  resource  management.  It  has  been  successfully 
implemented  by  many  countries,  most  notably  Malaysia  and  Canada.  More  and  more 
                                                 
14  ADB is currently preparing the program completion report for the ADB-funded Access to Justice Program in 
Pakistan, which will examine options for moving forward in this area in Pakistan.  
15  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
16 ADB. Pakistan Resident Mission. 2009. Pakistan Country Partnership Strategy 2009-2013. Islamabad, Pakistan.

9
developing  countries  are  adopting  RBM.  Punjab  is  keen  to  benefit  from  the  lessons  of 
successful international experiences on implementing RBM. 
 
36.  The RBM CPA ties in closely with the other reform areas of the Program. The inclusion 
of this new CPA demonstrates that programs need to be regularly evaluated and reengineered 
for better outcomes. As such, reform programs need to retain flexibility in adjusting policy 
actions to respond to changing circumstances and incorporating lessons learned.       
 
37.  Align development partner support with governments' own reform agenda. Strong 
government  ownership  is  a  prerequisite  for  successful  program  implementation.  The 
implementation  of  the  PRMP  and  PGEIP  subprogram  1  indicates  that  assistance  from 
development partners plays a catalytic role in setting desired changes in motion, provided that 
there is strong government ownership and commitment. External assistance by itself cannot 
substitute for government commitment and actions. The policy agenda needs to be backed by 
broader country or provincial reforms that are owned and driven by the government.     
 
38.  Cultivate broad support for reforms. Program reforms should have strong stakeholder 
support. The PGEIP has particularly benefited from this strength. The new government that 
came into power in February 2008 took time to review the program and has taken full ownership 
from September 2008. While this change of government delayed implementation somewhat, the 
program gained stronger momentum after the government's review. The PGEIP supported 
regular  stakeholder  consultation  and  active  change-management  efforts,  which  have  been 
essential for designing reforms that are owned, understood, and supported by key stakeholders.  
 
39.  Align resources and incentives with desired outcomes. Most programs involve one 
executing agency (EA) and several implementing agencies (IAs). Implementation arrangements 
need to strike a balance between fostering the central role of the EA and creating ownership in 
each IA.  
 
40.  Allow sufficient time for TA implementation. The implementation time for past TA 
was  often  too  short,  leaving  insufficient  time  for  recruiting  firms  as  opposed  to  individual 
consultants. The management of a large number of individual consultants complicates quality 
control. TA design needs to allow at least 1 year for recruiting firms in the case of Pakistan, 
given the tight supply of qualified consultants. Procurement and implementation procedures 
need to be simplified to increase efficiency, while building in strong accountability mechanisms.   
 
41.  Build reform momentum. Programs may target complex reform areas, which require 
sustained implementation for reforms to deliver desired benefits over the long term. While 
complex reforms need to be confronted, often overlooked are the easy wins and the low-
hanging fruit that can demonstrate sorely needed early success and give impetus to reforms. 
Thus, while an ambitious reform agenda is commendable, programs should include achievable 
results over the shorter term to sustain momentums for reforms.  
 
42.  Country-specific lessons were identified by the Country Assistance Program Evaluation17 
for Pakistan. The Country Assistance Program Evaluation found that the success of large ADB 
programs  was  hindered  by  covering  too  many  sectors  with  too  few staff,  complex  project 
designs,  and  inadequate  analytical  work.  The  completion  report  for  the  Pakistan  Country 
Strategy and Program 2002–200618 observed that reforms in Pakistan advance incrementally 
                                                 
17  ADB, Operations Evaluation Department. 2007. Country Assistance Program Evaluation for Pakistan. Manila.  
18  ADB. 2008. Pakistan Country Strategy and Program 2002–2006 Completion Report. Islamabad.

10  
and that there was a need for continued ADB support. ADB’s new program-centered approach 
in the social sectors has the potential to demonstrate better results than the earlier project-
based support for education, health, and water supply and sanitation. The Country Assistance 
Program  Evaluation  and  Country  Strategy  and  Program  completion  report  observed  that 
reforms need to be constantly fine-tuned to ensure they remain relevant and responsive to the 
country’s needs.  
  
43.  The PGEIP has incorporated these lessons. It is closely aligned with the government 
vision  and  strategy  and  ADB's  long-term  strategy  and  the  Pakistan  Country  Partnership 
Strategy, (2009-2013). It adopts a flexible cluster approach that takes into consideration the 
political economy of reforms, as reflected in the sequencing, and gradually builds upon and 
increases the depth and breadth of reforms. The PGEIP reflects strong ownership by relevant 
departments. Because of these strengths, the PGEIP has remained on track despite changes in 
political leadership in the province.  
 
IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
44.  Punjab today is home to 87 million people, and is still a relatively underdeveloped 
province: per capita income is low, poverty is high, there are many infrastructure bottlenecks, 
and  the  provision  of  social  services  is  inadequate.  The  government  wants  to  change  this 
situation. It has identified accelerating income growth and improving social services as its twin 
development  objectives.  Punjab’s  Vision  2020  envisages  Punjab  as  a  reasonably  well-off, 
educated, and healthy society by 2020, with the doubling of per capita income to $2,000. 
Guided  by  Vision  2020,  Punjab's  medium-term  development  framework  for  FY2008–2011 
highlights the need to develop a productive private sector and strengthen public institutions. The 
government is adopting a province-wide results based framework to define development targets 
and monitor progress in key sectors, including education, health, irrigation and power, transport, 
water supply and sanitation, livestock and dairy, and revenue.    
 
45.  The province requires large investment to realize its vision and development results. The 
major public sector revenue sources include the province's own source revenue, fiscal transfers 
from  the  federal  government,  and  development  assistance  from  development  agencies. 
Development assistance plays an important role in supplementing domestic savings. In addition 
to public investment, the province increasingly needs to benefit from greater private investment. 
Indeed, the lion's share of provincial investment is made by the private sector. The government 
needs to enable greater private sector participation not only in economic sectors, but also in 
financing and provision of infrastructure and social services. Achieving Punjab's development 
results  also  requires  the  province  to  use  its  scarce  resources  efficiently.  The  institutional 
foundation  for  achieving  Punjab's  development  objectives  is  an  efficient,  accountable,  and 
capable public sector19. This strategic consideration underpins the design of the PGEIP. The 
recent worsening of economic conditions has accentuated the urgency of such reforms. The 
overview of Punjab's Vision, strategic objectives, key impact and outcome indicators, resource 
envelop, and reforms are outlined in Figure 2.

B.  Impact and Outcome 
46.  The  PGEIP  supports  the  government's  dual  objectives  of  promoting  growth  and 
improving service delivery. The impact of the PGEIP will be high, sustained, and private sector–
driven growth, as well as improved service delivery. The outcome of the PGEIP will be an 
efficient, accountable, and enabling government that is capable of using scarce public resources 
for the benefit of citizens. The program structure is presented in Figure 3.

47.  The subprogram 2 supports reforms in five CPAs: 
 
(i)  CPA1. Improve public financial management by (a) adopting an output-based 
medium-term budgetary framework, and (b) widening the tax base and improving 
tax administration.  
(ii)  CPA2. Strengthen contingent liability management by improving the financing, 
investment, and management of pension and GP Fund expenses, as well as the 
record-keeping and administration for pension and GP Fund schemes.  
(iii)  CPA3. Improve civil service management by strengthening civil service function, 
business processes, human resource management, and capacity.  
(iv)  CPA4. Enable private sector development by promoting PPP for infrastructure 
development and social service delivery.  
(v)  CPA5. Enhance development results by adopting an RBM framework. 
 
48.  CPA5, adopting RBM, is introduced in subprogram 2 to promote a paradigm change 
from activities to results-based public sector management. This CPA is closely linked with the 
other four CPAs: while RBM clearly maps out development results, effective public financial 
management, human resource management, and private sector development are key building 
blocks for the successful implementation of RBM. The design and monitoring framework is 
outlined in Appendix 1. The development policy letter is in Appendix 4. The policy matrix is in 
Appendix 5, and the explanation on how the policy matrix has evolved is presented in Appendix 
6. An action plan for achieving subprogram 2 is in Supplementary Appendix C, while a program 
implementation  memorandum  (PAM)  is  in  Supplementary  Appendix  D.  The  reform  actions 
under each CPA are described below.

C.  Output and Activities of Subprogram 2 
1.  CPA1: Improve Public Financial Management 
50.  The objective of this CPA is to improve public financial management to promote the 
efficient and accountable use of scarce public resources.  
  
a.  Improve Expenditure Management 
51.  Implement output-based budgeting. A key reform in the PGEIP is the use of the 
MTBF to improve efficiency, accountability, and predictability in public financial management. 
Subprogram  1  institutionalized  the  explicit  estimation  of  the  province's  overall  resource 
envelope and strategic sector allocations by introducing the top–down dimension of the MTBF. 
Subprogram 2 introduced bottom–up output-based budgeting in two key departments, DOH and 
D&IP. The comprehensive MTBF strengthens budget preparation in three aspects: (i) explicitly 
communicating the amount of resources available to departments to enforce fiscal discipline; (ii) 
linking  service  delivery  with  the  budget  allocation  through  unit  costing;  and  (iii) adopting 
multiyear forward planning to improve budget credibility and predictability.  
 
52.  Output-based  budgeting  represents  a  paradigm  shift  from  incremental  input-based 
budgeting to results, so that it becomes possible to monitor and evaluate the cost-effectiveness 
of public spending. In DOH, for example, there has been significant under-budgeting of non-
salary recurrent expenditure, such as medicine and O&M, through the years. This component is 
vital for service delivery. Under the MTBF, the current expenditure of DOH for FY2010 is about 
70% higher than that for FY2009. The reduction in the mismatch between expenditures and 
outputs, and between expenditure components, improves efficiency in using public resources. 
MTBF  implementation  will  be  rolled  out  in three  more  departments  in  subprogram  3.  The

16  
government has tentatively identified them as E&TD, Livestock and Dairy Department (L&DD), 
and Department of Higher Education.    
 
53.  Spring  cleaning  of  ADP.  Budget  allocation  since  2009  has  been  tilted  toward 
completing ongoing schemes with the allocation of 70% of resources, with the remaining 30% 
allocated for new schemes. The government has taken measures to rationalize the FY2010 
ADP. The number of schemes with token allocations was reduced by about 25% compared with 
the  previous  year,20 and  block  allocations  was  reduced  in  both  number  and  size.  The 
government approved 70% of unapproved schemes in the first quarter of FY2010, equivalent to 
the share of approved schemes for the whole FY2009. In subprogram 3, the government will 
incorporate rules in the planning manual to remove ongoing schemes whose present allocations 
are less than 10% of the financing needs and eliminate most new schemes where the allocation 
is less than 15% of the financing needs. The government has committed to reduce the number 
of unapproved schemes by at least 90% by the second quarter of each FY starting from 
FY2011. This will help to mitigate the phenomenon of “too many projects, too few funds” and 
reduce time and cost overruns.  
 
54.  Greater accountability in budget execution. The prevalence of supplementary grants 
negates  the  precision  and  discipline  gained  from  the  MTBF.  Subprogram  2  supports  the 
institutionalization of pre-budget consultations with the provincial assembly. This dialogue allows 
legislators' concerns to be considered at an early stage of the budget process. This is expected 
to reduce demand for supplementary budgets and ad hoc development projects. As the costing 
of  outputs  within  the  resource  envelope  under  the  MTBF  improves,  the  government  has 
instituted ceilings on net supplementary grants for the two pilot MTBF departments.21   
 
b.  Improve tax administration and structure 
55.  Tax administration reforms will be actively pursued in subprogram 3, with some activities 
begun under subprogram 2. The property survey to support UIPT collection was initiated in July 
2009 and is expected to be completed by December 2009. Concurrently, the annual rental 
valuation tables will be updated to reflect more recent rental values by December 2009. On the 
MVT, the E&TD expects to implement online collection of the tax through commercial banks 
during subprogram 3. This will be supported by completing the rollout of the motor vehicle 
database to all districts in Punjab. E&TD institutional capacity—staff, functional structure, and 
business processes for tax administration—will be addressed in the civil service reform (CSR) 
component,  as  E&TD  is  one  of  the  two  departments  that  will  undergo  business  process 
reengineering.   
 
2.  CPA2: Manage Contingent Liabilities 
56.  The objective of this component is to manage the growing burden of pension and GP 
Fund expenditures and liabilities on provincial finances sustainably and efficiently.  
 
a.  Improve Financing and Reporting  
57.  Funding. The government will not reach the funding target set in 2007 for subprogram 1 
to accumulate PRs100 billion by FY2016 because of a number of developments. First, resource 
                                                 
20  New schemes with allocations of less than 10% of project cost are considered token allocations.  
21  Net supplementary grants refer to funding of proposed expenditures that are not funded by savings within the grant 
controlled by the administrative department. Such net supplementary grant requests are submitted to the Finance 
Department for its approval.

17
shortfalls arose from worsening economic conditions and reduced development partner support. 
Second, there have been changes to the government's priorities with increased expenditure 
outlay to counter increased poverty and security risks. Third, poor economic conditions and high 
inflation mean few investment opportunities are generating positive returns.   
 
58.  The government remains committed to addressing the growing pension and GP Fund 
liabilities. In FY2009, it transferred PRs6 billion to the PPF. For FY 2010, PRs6 billion was 
transferred in August 2009. The government prepared a revised funding strategy that takes into 
account  current  fiscal  conditions  (Supplementary  Appendix  B).  From  FY2011  onward,  the 
government will stop borrowing GP Fund contributions deducted from the employees' salaries 
and transfer the amount to the General Provident Investment Fund (GPIF). At the same time, it 
will initiate the amortization of GP Fund liabilities. The government will continue transferring 
funds to the PPF and use the funds as a buffer for unexpected pension outlays or government 
revenue shortfalls. Both the financing and investment strategies will be updated regularly to 
reflect changing needs, the maturity of the institutional mechanism, and fiscal conditions.     
 
59.  Governance  structure.  The  governance  structure  of  the  PPF  adopted  under 
subprogram  1  has  been  implemented  under  subprogram  2.  A  management  committee 
comprised of six ex-officio members and four private sector members has been created and 
meets regularly. Four subcommittees, investment, human resource, governance, and accounts 
and compliance, have been formed. In August 2009, a general manager was hired from the 
private sector; the trustee, legal advisor, and external auditor were appointed; and the signing 
authority of the pension account was transferred to the PPF. An investment policy for PPF was 
approved by the management committee in October 2008. The GPIF Act was adopted by the 
provincial  assembly  on  2  July  2009.  In  the  future,  both  the  PPF  and  GPIF  funds  will  be 
managed  by  the  same  management  committee  to  minimize  operational  costs  and  share 
professional expertise.  
 
60.  Accounting for pension and GP Fund costs. The government reports pension and 
GP Fund costs based on annual benefit payments. To assess the solvency and sustainability of 
the pension scheme, it is necessary to look at long-term costs on an accrual basis. Under 
subprogram 2, the government, for the first time, reported on the current cost and accrued 
liabilities of the pension and GP Fund based on an actuarial valuation using June 2008 data 
contained in the white paper for FY2010. The government will report on the current cost and 
accrued liabilities of the pension and GP Fund in line with International Public Sector Accounting 
Standard 25,22 as a supplement to the budget starting from the next fiscal year.    
 
b.  Improve Record-Keeping and Administration   
61.  Under subprogram 1, the Finance Department created the Pension Administration Task 
Force (PAT), which is responsible for improving the administration of pension and GP Fund 
expenses. Under subprogram 2, a baseline has been introduced to monitor the progress of data 
gathering, verification, and entry for payroll, pension, and GP Fund records into the SAP/R3 
database. As of 10 August 2009, over 988,000 employees were paid through the SAP/R3 
human resource module, and 782,000 GP Fund accounts and 162,000 pension records were 
registered. Substantial progress has been made in collecting pension record data. Across the 
province, over 90% of pension records have been entered into excel files. About half of the 
                                                 
22 The International Accounting Board has selected a particular actuarial method as the standard for pension 
accounting to ensure that pension expenses reported by different entities are comparable. Projected unit cost  is an 
accrual accounting method in which the required assets correspond to the accrued liabilities and the annual cost 
corresponds to the value of the benefits earned for that year of service.

18  
computerized  data  had  been  uploaded  into  the  SAP/R3  database.  Although  most  of  the 
employees have a GP Fund account, these accounts are far from complete. About 20% of 
historic GP Fund records have been converted from ledger books into the SAP/R3 database. A 
pilot project has been initiated to test alternative methods that may speed the process.    
 
3.  CPA3: Forge Civil Service Reforms 
62.  The objective of this component is to foster an efficient, accountable, and capable civil 
service.    
 
a.  Improve Functions, Streamline Business Processes, and Modernize 
Human Resource Management in the Civil Service 
63.  Adopting a civil service reform policy. The daunting challenge confronting CSR in 
Punjab necessitates an incremental approach toward introducing sustainable changes. To guide 
reforms and enable departments to adopt human resource management practices that depart 
from the existing rules and regulations, the provincial cabinet approved a CSR policy in August 
2009 which sets out the government's intention and commitment to modernize the civil service 
(Supplementary Appendix E). The policy articulates key parameters for reforms, including the 
role  of  government,  open  and  merit-based  posting  and  recruitment,  modern  compensation 
packages, stable tenure, skills development, simplified business processes, and rewards linked 
with service delivery indicators.      
 
64.  Reforming departments. The government identified two key departments, E&TD and 
L&DD, to undergo a full-fledged functional review, business process reengineering, and human 
resource management reform. While E&TD is a key provincial revenue office, L&DD supports a 
sector that generates about 40% of farmers' income. Functional review is especially important 
for L&DD. In addition to providing extensive services, the department provides animal nutrition 
and vaccines and owns farms. Encouraging private sector participation in the livestock and dairy 
sector will reduce the administrative burden of the government and improve efficiency in using 
resources such as land. The government is considering leasing out most of the farms to the 
private sector. As 80% of dairy sector work is managed by women, improved the functioning of 
this department will help to empower women by increasing their income.   
 
65.  Business process reengineering in L&DD and E&TD will reduce redundant processes 
and improve operational efficiency, supported by the use of information technology. Human 
resource management reforms strengthen incentives for better service delivery. These include 
introducing open and merit-based recruitment and posting, linking compensation with skills and 
performance, stabilizing tenure, monetarizing benefits, outsourcing nonessential functions, and 
transforming the civil service from a large unskilled structure into skilled institutions.      
 
66.  Modernizing  recruitment.  A  major  complaint  against  the  Punjab  Public  Service 
Commission (PPSC) is its slow response to departments' recruitment requests. Supported by 
the subprogram 2, the PPSC adopted a new procedure in August 2009 to move away from 
interviewing  all  candidates  to  only  those  who  are  shortlisted.  This  will  significantly  reduce 
recruitment  time.  The  effort  to  introduce  simplified  business  processes  and  a  recruitment 
management system using information technology will continue into subprogram 3 and beyond.  
 
67.  Benchmarking Performance. Designing an evidence-based performance-management 
system is a key support for reforms. This program supports benchmarking to identify and 
measure key performance indicators. Comprehensive benchmarking will be carried out initially

19
in  E&TD,  L&DD,  and  PPSC,  focusing  on  strategic,  functional,  performance,  and  process 
aspects. While PPSC benchmarking has been completed, work for E&TD and L&DD has started. 
Over time, benchmarking performance will constitute an important part of the performance 
management system throughout the province.   
 
b.  Strengthen Civil Servant Capacity 
68.  The number of training days conducted by MPDD almost doubled from 2007 to 2008 
and increased a further 20% from 2008 to 2009. The training subjects include provincial policies 
and regulations; technical matters such as financial management, project management, and 
computer  skills;  and  personal  skills  such  as  problem  solving,  decision  making,  and 
communications.  Gender-sensitization  workshops  have  been  held  and  are  supported  by 
subprogram 2. MPDD training infrastructure has improved significantly. Its facilities are now 
rented by other organizations, creating additional income for the government. MPDD will adopt 
a management information system to improve the efficiency of training by 2009. A training 
strategy was developed during subprogram 2 to transform the training initiative in the province 
from  supply  based  to  demand  driven,  providing  increased  autonomy  and  incentives  to 
departments and staff.    
 
4.  CPA4: Enable Private Sector Development 
69.  The objective of this CPA is to promote PPP for higher economic growth and better 
service delivery. Subprogram 2 supports the development of an enabling environment for PPP 
of infrastructure and social services, especially education and health services. A framework was 
prepared in April 2009 to outline a road map for developing PPP (Supplementary Appendix F). 
A  PPP  policy  was  approved  in  August  2009  by  the  provincial  cabinet  to  articulate  the 
government's intention to adopt PPP for infrastructure and social service delivery. A PPP law 
was prepared and discussed with stakeholders, and submitted in August 2009 to the provincial 
assembly. A series of training workshops have been held for key line departments. During 
subprogram  3,  the  PPP  Cell  established  in  subprogram  1  will  be  complemented  by  the 
establishment of a senior policy board chaired by the chief secretary. The experience of federal 
government PPP reforms demonstrates that PPP development should include opportunities to 
learn by doing through actual project development, which will help sustain government interest 
and commitment toward PPP. While the government continues to develop PPP regulatory 
frameworks, it has also made efforts to support PPP project development. Project development 
facility  (PDF)  guidelines  was  approved  by  the  provincial  cabinet  in  August  2009,  and  the 
government has allocated $1 million funds in the FY2010 budget for the facility and identified a 
list of potential PPP projects.23   
 
5.  CPA5: Adopt Results-Based Management  
70.  This  is  a  new  CPA  which  helps  the  government  to  adopt  modern  public  sector 
management techniques to achieve its vision. Punjab has developed a draft result framework 
through a consultative process to shift its development agenda from inputs and activities toward 
greater accountability for results. The key sectors included in the framework are education, 
health, water supply and sanitation, irrigation and power, transport, livestock and dairy, and 
excise and taxation. Punjab's RBM framework pays particular attention to achieving positive 
gender results, especially in health and education, to contribute to achieving the MDGs.  
                                                 
23 Any PPP project developed with support from the PGEIP will be designed taking into consideration applicable 
government and ADB environmental and safeguard requirements.

20  
 
71.  Punjab's  RBM  framework  focuses  on  results  (outputs,  outcomes,  and  impact)  and 
emphasizes the need to efficiently use resources. Adopting sound public financial management, 
human resource management, efficient business processes, and monitoring and evaluation 
systems form an essential part of RBM. There is also a great need to streamline the role of the 
government and enable the private sector to deliver results. The focus to deliver development 
results underpins the five CPAs in the PGEIP. The linkages between Punjab's development 
results  and  the  ADB's  strategic  focus  provide  a  platform  for  the  ADB  to  assist  Punjab's 
development through both providing financing and supporting reforms. The overview of Punjab's 
RBM framework is set out in Figure 2, and the details of Punjab's RBM framework are outlined 
in Supplementary Appendix G.    
 
6.  Gender Focus of the Program 
72.  Subprogram 2 of the PGEIP mainstreams gender reforms and supports gender equity in 
Punjab24, building upon past ADB support to Pakistan under the Decentralization Support 
Program. The subprogram 2 action plan (see Supplementary Appendix C and Table 2) includes 
a number of gender-specific actions. Over 2004–2007, the Decentralization Support Program 
supported the Government of Pakistan in developing the national Gender Reform Action Plan 
(GRAP), which was later approved by the National Assembly, and provincial GRAPs that were 
approved by provincial assemblies or cabinets. Promoting gender equity is an important part of 
subprogram 2, especially in CPA1 (improving public financial management), CPA3 (civil service 
reforms), and CPA5 (adopting RBM).  
 
73.  The government has begun to orient budget and planning processes toward increased 
attention to promoting gender equity. Two pre-budget seminars were conducted to increase 
awareness on gender sensitive budgeting in FY2010. While still small, resource allocation for 
GRAP implementation has more than doubled during subprogram 2, from PRs70 million in 
FY2008 to PRs148 million in FY2010.   
 
74.  Gender  mainstreaming  units  have  been  established  in  seven  key  departments: 
education, health, finance, planning and development, home, law, and services and general 
administration. Gender support units have been established in 27 districts. The gender support 
units conducted a review of 179 project documents. Based upon the review, these project 
documents were revised to reflect better gender balance. MTBF helped to significantly increase 
budget for the health sector in FY2010. The ADP for health and education includes a clear focus 
on  bridging  the  gap  in  services  and  infrastructure  available  to  male  and  females.  The 
government prepared gendered budget statements for the districts of Rajanpur and Gujrat to 
gauge whether public investment is gender responsive. The findings were incorporated into the 
gender aspects section of the budget call circular for FY2010. Subprogram 3 will further deepen 
and  institutionalize  gender-sensitive  public  financial  management  by  introducing  gender-
responsive budgeting in the health and education departments.    
 
75.  The livestock and dairy sector contributes 11% of provincial GDP and employs 30 million 
people, largely in rural areas. Women play an important role in animal husbandry. Over 90% of 
fresh milk consumed in Pakistan is derived from small domestic production, which is mainly 
managed by women. The government realizes the importance of this sector. Budget allocation 
for livestock and dairy more than doubled to PRs1,640 million in FY2010 from PRs806 million in 
                                                 
24 Subprogram 2 of PGEIP has been categorized as an effective gender mainstreaming program by the Regional 
Sustainable Development Department and the program team.

21
FY2009. The initiatives will improve productivity in this sector and augment the earning power of 
women. Lack of economic empowerment is a major problem facing women in Punjab.  
 
76.  CPA3 supports the establishment of institutions that enable gender equity. The GRAP 
project  will  conclude  in  June  2010.  Anticipating  this  and  the  continuous  need  for  gender-
sensitive  interventions,  the  government  has  established  the  Directorate  of  Women’s 
Development  to  be  responsible  for  sustainably  carrying  out  GRAP  activities.  The  PGEIP 
supports the conduct of a series of sensitization workshops on gender equity to raise awareness 
of gender issues and to mainstream gender equity in the reform agenda. Benchmarking and in-
depth functional review, business process reengineering, and human resource management 
reforms in L&DD will improve the performance of the dairy sector and boost woman's earning 
power. Gender equity will be a regular training topic in the MPDD curriculum in subprogram 3.  
 
77.  Bridging the gender gap is a core element of Punjab's RBM framework, especially in 
health  and  education.  The  RBM  framework  working  group  will  report  both  progress  and 
shortfalls in achieving the indicators to the provincial cabinet and assembly. The realization of 
concrete outcome indicators in key sectors, such as eliminating the gender disparity in primary 
school  enrollment,  will  go  a  long  way  toward  improving  the  welfare  of  women  and  other 
vulnerable  groups  in  Punjab.  Subprogram  3  will  support  the  assessment  of  GRAP 
implementation regarding public financial management, civil service reforms, service delivery, 
and  economic  empowerment  aspects;  and  the  deepening  of  gender  mainstreaming 
interventions. Table 2 summarizes gender initiatives included in the subprogram 2 action plan.

D.  Important Features 
78.  Introducing result based management. The PGEIP is introducing RBM in Punjab, 
which is characterized by focus and accountability for results. RBM serves as an overarching 
framework linking development results with effective and efficient systems and procedures. The 
first four CPAs of the PGEIP aim to equip the government with efficient, accountable, and 
enabling financial, human resource, information, and monitoring and evaluation systems for 
delivering results, while the new fifth CPA integrates long-term goals, medium-term outcomes, 
and short-term actions.  
 
79.  Deepening the long-term reform agenda and sharpening the focus on results. The 
PGEIP has evolved to include a few strategic reform areas focusing on delivering results. This 
departs from past programs that were overburdened by scattered and numerous actions.  
 
80.  Sustained government ownership. Vision 2020 and the MTBF articulate the need for 
an efficient, effective, and responsive government, as well as a dynamic and productive private 
sector.  Extensive  dialogue  with  the  government  and  consultations  with  stakeholders  have 
ensured that all four CPAs of the PGEIP are in close alignment with the government’s policy 
directions.  Ongoing  consultation  with  stakeholders  will  help  ensure  sustained  support  for 
reforms despite political and leadership changes. The current government, which came to 
power in February 2008, has strongly embraced program reforms.     
 
81.  Integrated program design. The PGEIP is consistent with ADB's Strategy 2020 and the 
Country Partnership Strategy for Pakistan, and it complements operations by ADB and other 
development partners. Its CPAs are integrated. For example, public financial management 
reforms link resource allocation with performance, while business process reengineering in 
E&TD under CSR complement tax administration reforms.  
 
82.  Introducing the program administration memorandum. A PAM has been developed 
by ADB and the government to monitor program progress and facilitate reform implementation. 
The PAM is an evolving tool that maps out the actions to be taken and the responsibilities of 
agencies  and  individuals,  and  monitors  progress.  The PAM  will  be  a  useful instrument  to 
support the PGEIP and TA implementation and communications among and within the ADB and 
government teams.

23
 
83.  Gender mainstreaming. Effective gender mainstreaming is an important part of the 
PGEIP, especially in the areas of public financial management, civil service reform, and RBM. 
Gender mainstreaming will be regularly evaluated and deepened as program implementation 
proceeds.  
 
E.  Financing Plan 
84.  Loan size, terms, and conditions. Two loans with an aggregate amount of $150 million 
equivalent will be provided to finance subprogram 2 of the PGEIP. The first loan of $75 million 
will be financed from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined according 
to ADB's London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; a 15-year term, including 
a grace period of 3 years; a commitment charge of 0.15% per annum; and other terms and 
conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. The Government of Pakistan has provided ADB 
with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility under 
these terms and conditions and (ii) an undertaking that these choices were its own independent 
decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. The second loan 
of $75 million equivalent will be financed from ADB Special Funds resources with a term of 24 
years including a grace period of 8 years; an interest rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace 
period and 1.5% thereafter; and other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. 
The borrower will be Pakistan.   
 
85.  Financing of subprograms 2 and 3 were provisionally estimated in subprogram 1 at $250 
million each. Subprogram 2 has been scaled back in light of the exceptional financing needs at 
the national level. The government has requested that $250 million be provided for subprogram 
3 as originally envisaged. The loan size and composition of subprogram 3 will be confirmed 
during processing on the bases of progress, financing requirements, and the availability of 
resources.
