86.  The primary reason for the government to seek ADB policy and financial support is to 
carry out institutional reforms toward an efficient, accountable, and capable government. The 
financial,  economic,  and  political  costs  associated  with  the  reforms  are  substantial.  Direct 
adjustment  costs  include  (i)  costs  for  results-oriented  budgeting  in  key  social  sector  and 
infrastructure  departments,  specifically  relating  to  bridging  the  gaps  caused  by  chronic 
underfunding of nonrecurrent expenditure in the incremental and input-based budget system; 
(ii) the capitalization of PPF and GPIF; (iii) increased wage costs as civil service reforms bring 
compensation more in line with the market rate; (iv) support of PPP projects in infrastructure 
and social services, and (v) costs to support consensus building (Table 3). 
 
87.  Earlier discussion on the use of the program proceeds focused on pension and GP Fund 
capitalization. The government modified this focus for the following reasons: (i) slow growth and 
high inflation in Pakistan has made it difficult to find investment opportunities that generate 
positive  returns;  (ii)  the  reduction  in  government  revenue  and  delayed  disbursement  and 
reduction in funds available from ADB programs have made unfeasible pursuing the initial 
pension and GP Fund path; (iii) based on the updated actuarial assessment and changed 
macroeconomic  situation,  the  updated  pension  financing  strategy  provides  for  slower 
accumulation in the next 5 years; (iv) the need to weigh pensions and GP Fund against other 
adjustment costs and financing needs suggests a more balanced approach in using program 
proceeds. Subprogram 2 proceeds will thus be used to partly cover all areas of reform costs. 
 
88.  The adjustment costs of PGEIP reforms are substantial. Program proceeds will only 
partly  cover  the  adjustment  costs.  The  government  needs  to  generate  resources  through 
improved efficiency. In public financial management, for example, rationalization of development 
plans and recurrent expenditure is needed to create fiscal space. In some cases, expenditure 
will need to be reduced based on the government's strategic priorities and resource constraints. 
In pension and GP Fund management, the funding pace has slowed, partly reflecting the 
government's resource constraints. In civil service reforms, while the wage compression of 
skilled employees needs to be addressed, the number of unskilled employees needs to be 
reduced to create fiscal space and make better use of the province's human resources. Fringe 
benefits need to monetarized and rationalized to create a more liquid, more transparent, and 
less  wasteful  compensation  system.  In  private  sector  development,  while  developing  PPP 
projects requires initial public funding, it will bring more resources and better utilization of 
resources over time. The reforms under PGEIP subprogram 2 entail short-term costs, but 
Punjab will draw larger benefits over the long run. 
 
89.  Relending. The Government of Pakistan will relend the local currency generated from 
the proceeds of the loans to the Government of Punjab under the same terms and conditions as 
those  extended  by  ADB  to  Pakistan.  The  Government  of  Punjab  will  assume  the  foreign 
exchange and interest rate risks. 
 
F.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Program Management 
 
90.  P&DD is the EA. The steering committee established under subprogram 1 continues to 
guide  PGEIP  implementation.  The  executive  committee  chaired  by  the  P&DD  chairman 
supports the steering committee and ensures efficient implementation. The executive committee

25
meets  at  least  twice  a  year  and  oversees  program  implementation.  To  increase  program 
ownership among the IAs, the executive committee includes the IAs working on the specific 
reform area concerned. Membership thus changes according to the specific area covered. ADB 
may be invited to participate in executive committee meetings as an observer. Each CPA has 
dedicated focal departments. The Finance Department is responsible for implementing CPAs 1 
and 2, the Service and General Administration Department is coordinating CPA3, and P&DD is 
in charge of CPAs 4 and 5. A RBM working group has been established to develop and monitor 
the implementation the results and report its findings to the provincial cabinet and assembly. 
The PMU established under the PRMP in 2003 is the secretariat of the steering and executive 
committees. A PAM using Microsoft Project has been prepared to assist and monitor progress 
(Supplementary Appendix D). PGEIP subprogram 2 implementation has been supported by the 
TA loan and TA grant for the PGEIP program cluster. 
 
2.  Implementation Period 
 
91.  The  implementation  period  of  PGEIP  is  from  July  2006  to  around  March  2011. 
Subprogram 2 covers reform measures implemented from January 2008 to September 2009. 
The proposal on the subprogram 3 loan will be submitted for Board consideration about 18–20 
months  after  loan  effectiveness  for  the  subprogram  2  loans,  subject  to  the  governments' 
continued commitment to the reform agenda and adequate reform progress. 
 
92.  To  guide  reform  actions,  an  action  plan  for  subprogram  3  was  developed  during 
subprogram 2 implementation. While the government is committed to implementing key reform 
principles, the action plan will be a working document and actions therein will be adjusted where 
needed to address unforeseen situations, in close coordination with ADB.  
 
3.  Tranches and Counterpart Financing 
 
93.  The proceeds from the two loans will be available for withdrawal in a single tranche 
subject to satisfaction of all subprogram 2 policy actions and following loan effectiveness. 
 
94.  The government will ensure that the local currency generated from the proceeds of the 
loans  will  be  used,  first,  to  support  the  adjustment  costs  of  reforms  to  be  initiated  and 
implemented under subprogram 2 and, second, to finance expenditures for the government’s 
general development purposes.  
 
4.  Procurement and Disbursement Arrangements 
 
95.  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange costs (excluding 
local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured in ADB member countries, excluding 
ineligible items (Appendix 7) and imports25 financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources. 
The loan proceeds will be disbursed to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan, the Borrower, in 
accordance  with  the  provisions  of  ADB’s  Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and 
Related  Requirements  for  Program  Loans.26 No  supporting  import  documentation  will  be 
required if, during each year that loan proceeds are expected to be disbursed, the value of 
Pakistan’s  total  imports  minus  imports  from  nonmember  countries,  ineligible  imports,  and 
imports financed under other official development assistance is equal to or greater than the 
                                                 
25 Eligible imports minus imports from nonmember countries, imports specified on the list of ineligible items, and 
imports financed by ADB or other international and bilateral development agencies. 
26 ADB. 1998. Simplification of Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans. Manila.

26  
amount of the loan expected to be disbursed during that year. The Government of Pakistan will 
certify  its  compliance  with  this  formula  in  its  withdrawal  request.  Otherwise,  import 
documentation under existing procedures will be required. Disbursements will be made under 
the simplified procedures for program loans. 
 
5.  Anticorruption, Fiduciary Issues, Accounting, and Auditing 
 
96.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  governments  of  Pakistan  and  Punjab.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good 
governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or 
through its agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the 
Project. To support these efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included 
in  the  loan  regulations  and  bidding  documents  for  the  Project.  In  particular,  all  contracts 
financed by ADB in connection with the Project shall include provisions specifying the right of 
ADB  to  audit  and  examine  the  records  and  accounts  of  the  Executing  Agency  and  all 
contractors, suppliers, consultants, and other service providers as they relate to the Project. 
 
97.  Much progress has been made on accountability and auditing, with support from the 
PIFRA. The PGEIP will complement the government's anticorruption efforts. For instance, CPA1 
aims for an efficient and accountable public financial management regime.27 The introduction of 
accrued accounting and the automation of pension and GP Fund records under CPA2 will 
increase  transparency  and  minimize  the  scope  for  error  and  fraud  in  the  accounting  and 
disbursement  of  pension  benefits.  Human  resource  reforms  and  business  process 
reengineering under CPA3 will enhance transparency and reduce opportunities for corruption. 
The promotion of PPP under CPA4 will improve discipline in service delivery.   
 
6.  Performance Monitoring, Evaluation, and Program Review 
 
98.  The government and ADB have agreed on a range of outcome and output indicators to 
monitor PGEIP implementation and evaluate its impact within the program framework (Appendix 
1). The government and ADB will periodically review progress on PGEIP implementation. The 
government will keep ADB informed of the outcome of policy discussions with other multilateral 
and bilateral agencies that have implications for PGEIP implementation and provide ADB with 
the opportunity to comment on any resulting policy proposals. A review will be conducted by the 
executive committee every quarter, and a progress report will be shared with ADB, with the first 
progress report due on 31 December 2009. A summary of the progress report will be published 
on the PRMP website (http://www.punjab-prmp.gov.pk/). To assist monitoring and evaluation 
and guide implementation, a detailed action plan has been prepared for subprogram 3. PGEIP-
related information is widely disseminated to the public through a dedicated website. Regular 
workshops and meetings involving civil society will be organized by the PMU to seek ideas from 
the public and disseminate information. ADB will regularly carry out review missions to review 
progress and, based on the result, prepare subprogram 3.    
 
 
 
                                                 
27  CPA 1 (improve public financial management) is an important initiative for addressing and mitigating risks 
identified  in  the  country-level  risk  assessment  in  the  area  of  public  financial  management  in  the  Country 
Partnership Strategy, which was approved in March 2009. This is a good example of following through with action 
to address country-level risks identified during Country Partnership Strategy formulation through program reforms.

27
V.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACT, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Program Benefits 
99.  The PGEIP reinforces is expected to yield a number of benefits for the residents of 
Punjab, which are summarized below.   
 
100.  More efficient use of public financial resources. The shift from input- to output-based 
budgets  will  strengthen  efficiency and  accountability  in  the  use  of  public  resources.  It  will 
eliminate the mismatch between expenditure components, especially the squeeze on non-salary 
recurrent expenditure, thereby reducing waste and improving service delivery. By integrating 
planning  and  budgeting  processes,  the  PGEIP  will  ensure  greater  cohesion  between 
development priorities and fiscal resources. The integration of annual budgeting under the 
MTBF will make budgeting more predictable and disciplined. The increase of the GRAP budget 
will contribute to gender mainstreaming. All these actions will improve the use of scarce public 
resources and the provision of public services, especially to women and other vulnerable groups.       
 
101.  Greater financial sustainability for the pension system. The partial prefunding of 
pension  and  GP  Fund  costs  will  free  up  finances  and  reduce  contingent  liabilities.  The 
establishment of the PPF and GPIF will promote savings, which will contribute to financial sector 
development and economic growth. The improvement of pension and GP Fund record-keeping 
will reduce leakage and improve service delivery.    
 
102.  An  efficient,  accountable,  and  capable  civil  service.  Improved  human  resource 
management in the civil service will infuse merit and performance orientation and motivate civil 
servants  for  better  service  delivery.  Efficient  institutional  structures,  simpler  business 
procedures, better human resource management, and improved capacity in the public sector 
will improve the functioning of government. These efforts will help to transform the Punjab civil 
service from a rigid, hierarchical bureaucracy into a citizen-responsive organization capable of 
leveraging scarce resources and providing an environment that is conducive to private sector–
led growth. These reforms are fundamental to improved service delivery, especially to women 
and other vulnerable groups, and creating a better investment climate.  
 
103.  A  dynamic  private  sector.  The  establishment  of  policy,  institutional,  and  financial 
mechanisms for PPP will enable Punjab to benefit from the resources of both the private and 
the public sector for improved infrastructure and social service delivery, higher investment and 
growth, and more jobs.  
 
104.  Results-based  management.  The  adoption  of  RBM  will  transform  public  sector 
management  from  rigid  micro  control  to  greater  focus  on  results.  This  combination  of 
accountability for results and flexibility in management is the hallmark of modern public sector 
management and will usher in a paradigm change in government functions in Punjab. The result 
frameworks of the social sectors will contribute to improving the welfare of women and other 
vulnerable groups through increased focus on development results and better service delivery.  
 
105.  Gender benefits. Punjab's result framework explicitly spells out government targets for 
gender equity, particularly in health and education. One of the PGEIP's key target departments 
is livestock and dairy, in which women carry out 80% of activities. The government increased 
the livestock and dairy budget to PRs1,640 million in FY2010 from PRs806 million in FY2009. 
Improved function, business processes, and human resource management in L&DD will help to 
improve productivity in the sector and economically empower women. Building on Punjab's

28  
GRAP, the PGEIP helped to identify large funding gaps and increased budget allocation in the 
health sector, with positive benefits to woman and children through better access to medicine 
and improved medical facilities. Supported by the PGEIP, budgeting and planning processes in 
Punjab are paying increased attention to gender equity in allocations. Institutions tasked to work 
on gender equity, such as the Directorate of Women’s Development, have been set up to carry 
out GRAP activities. The PGEIP is conducting a series of sensitization workshops on gender 
equity in Punjab. All these efforts will contribute to women's welfare and empowerment. The 
summary poverty reduction and social strategy of the PGEIP is in Appendix 8. 
  
106.  The  institutional  reforms  embodied  in  the  PGEIP  will  improve  government  function 
across the board and are essential for good governance, economic growth, and improved public 
service delivery. The realization of these benefits requires commitment and determination from 
the government. The PGEIP's support and leverage are critical to keeping the reforms on track. 
 
B.  Program Impact 
107.  Fiscal space. The PGEIP will contribute to creating fiscal space by (i) reducing wastage 
in public expenditure through the MTBF, (ii) prefunding of pension and GP Fund costs to contain 
expenditure outlay, (iii) reducing pension and GP Fund leakage through better record-keeping, 
(v) developing an efficient civil service, and (vi) leveraging investment through PPP. 
 
108.  Institutional development. Increased coordination between planning and budgeting will 
promote a more coherent approach to public expenditure management, with significant gains in 
output-oriented financial management. An improved ADP will enhance the effectiveness of the 
government's development efforts. Establishing a professionally managed PPF and GPIF is a 
milestone for managing the funds in line with international best practice. Civil service reforms 
will bring across-the-board institutional improvement in the public sector. The establishment of 
the PPP Cell will strengthen the interface between the public and private sectors. The adoption 
of RBM will modernize public sector management in Punjab.  
  
109.  Service delivery and social impact. More efficient public resource management and 
improved civil service management will improve the quality of service delivery, especially in the 
education and health sectors. Improved management of contingent liabilities will strengthen the 
social safety net. The creation of fiscal space will allow more social spending, especially on 
vulnerable groups, including women.   
 
110.  Economic growth and poverty reduction. Improved public financial management will 
improve  value  for  money  in  public  spending  and  generate  resources  for  investment.  The 
establishment of the PPF and GPIF will contribute to investment and economic growth. The 
efficiency gains achieved through civil service reforms and private sector development will spur 
sustainable economic growth. Promoting PPPs will enable more resources for investment and 
the provision of more and better infrastructure and social services. The PGEIP will contribute to 
poverty  reduction  by  increasing  investment  and  the  expansion  of  income-generating 
opportunities, more and better social and development spending, and a more effective public 
sector that is geared towards service delivery outcomes. 
 
111.  Resettlement, indigenous people, and the environment. The PGEIP will cause no 
direct or indirect involuntary resettlement or  raise any issues affecting indigenous peoples 
(category C). It is also unlikely to have any adverse environmental impact (category C).

29
C.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
112.  Program design and implementation need to manage and mitigate a variety of risks. 
These are summarized below.    
 
113.  Security  risks.  The number of  violent assaults has increased in recent months in 
Pakistan,  with  the  frequency  of  such  incidents  increasing  in  Punjab.  The  Government  of 
Pakistan is implementing measures to contain security risks. Sustained economic growth and 
stability are necessary for achieving peace and prosperity in the country.   
 
114.  Political risks. Recent developments indicate a more cooperative approach between 
major political parties. The risk of reversing the direction of program reforms is low given the 
broad consensus on reforms.   
 
115.  Macroeconomic  risks.  The  Government  of  Pakistan  has  launched  a  stabilization 
program to improve the macroeconomic situation and restore investor confidence. ADB is a 
major partner through its support under the Accelerating Economic Transformation Program, 
which  provides  measures  to  deal  with  short-term  shocks  and  address  long-term  structural 
issues.  Signs  of  economic  recovery  have  emerged  recently.  Program  measures  to  tackle 
institutional  and  policy  impediments  to  growth  in  Punjab  will  help  to  reduce  economic 
vulnerability in the medium term. 
 
116.  Weak capacity. Program implementation may be delayed by weak capacity in a number 
of departments. With the help of a TA loan and grant, the PMU and departments involved are 
addressing capacity limitations. Enhancing IA ownership of the PGEIP has helped to mitigate 
implementation risks.  
 
117.  Intergovernmental coordination. The civil service reform component requires effective 
intergovernmental  coordination.  The  upfront  work  on  civil  service  reforms  has  been 
disseminated widely, including to those who may be affected. Change management forms an 
important part of program implementation to lessen resistance and increase support for reforms. 
 
VI.  ASSURANCES 
118.  In addition to the standard assurances, the Government of Pakistan has given the 
following assurances, which are to be incorporated into the loan agreements:  
 
(i)  the policies adopted and actions taken under subprogram 2, as set forth in the 
Development Policy Letter and the Policy Matrix, will be in effect for and beyond 
the duration of subprogram 2; and 
(ii)  based  on  the  recommendation  from  the  MTBF  assessment  report,  the 
Government of Punjab will provide the Finance Department with at least five (5) 
qualified technical staff designated for the implementation of the MTBF in the 
Budget Wing of the Finance Department by 31 November 2009. 
 
VII.  RECOMMENDATION 
119.  I am satisfied that the proposed loans would comply with the Articles of Agreement of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve

with ADB's London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; a term

per  annum;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in

presented to the Board; and 
(ii)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to Special Drawing Rights 48,298,000 to

period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft Loan and Program Agreements 
presented to the Board.

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
1.  This sector analysis provides a summary assessment of public financial management, 
pension and General Provident Fund (GP Fund) contingent liability management, civil service 
management, and private sector development.    
 
A.  Public Financial Management 
 
1.  Issues 
 
2.  As  part  of  the  Punjab  Resource  Management  Program  (PRMP),  the  Finance 
Department published its first medium-term budget framework (MTBF) in August 2004. However, 
this exercise was not subsequently updated annually. In fiscal year (FY) 2006, the Planning and 
Development  Department  (P&DD)  published  its  first  medium-term  development  framework 
(MTDF), providing sector overviews, strategies, and principal targets. Although this exercise has 
been  replicated  every  year,  these  reforms  are  piecemeal  and  lack  an  integrated  and 
programmatic  approach.  Further,  budget  reforms  in  Punjab  are  complicated  by  the  dual 
budgeting system in Pakistan. Current and development budgets are prepared separately from 
the  beginning  and  get  to  be  presented  together  only  at  a  very  late  stage,  i.e.,  prior  to 
presentation  to  the  provincial  assembly.  The  Punjab  Government  Efficiency  Improvement 
Program (PGEIP) sought to re-engage Punjab in budgeting reforms. Under subprogram 1, the 
Government of Punjab (the government) (i) adopted the MTBF for FY2008 to FY2010, (ii) 
approved joint protocols to enable the Finance Department and P&DD to jointly review the 
current and development budgets, and (iii) established units in the two pilot departments, the 
Department of Health (DOH) and the Department of Irrigation & Power (DI&P), that allow the 
preparation of consolidated departmental budgets. 
 
3.  Large  variations  in  expenditure  outturns. While the government has adopted a 
multiyear budget framework, expenditure outturns increasingly deviate from budget estimates 
(Table A3.1). In terms of total expenditure, the deviations of actual expenditures from original 
budget estimates have increased in recent years. Between FY2005 and FY2007, the deviations 
for aggregate expenditures were kept within ±5%. But this increased to –14.2% in FY2008 and 
9.3% in FY2009. For FY2008, this is largely attributable to the huge deviation in development 
expenditures (–25.2%). For FY2009, both current and development expenditures deviated from 
budget estimates by 8%–10%.1 The composition of expenditures also deviated significantly from 
the original budget estimates. Budget deviations in FY2008 and FY2009 were double digit for 
most  sectors.  These  deviations  and  reallocations  weaken  the  budget's  usefulness  as  a 
statement of policy intent.

4.  Incomplete MTBF implementation. The primary reason for the lack of precision in the 
budget is that the budgeting reforms are still incomplete. Thus far, reforms have focused on the 
top–down dimension, which is the fiscal framework, while budgeting at the department level has 
remained incremental. The next steps will include (i) prescribing budget ceilings for departments, 
(ii) improving department budgeting, and (iii) setting up a budget execution and monitoring 
system.  Political  instability  prevented  the  government  from  undertaking  subsequent  MTBF 
reforms in preparation of the FY2009 budget. The government was unable to roll out the top–
down fiscal framework for FY2009–FY2011. Further, budgeting reform in the pilot departments 
envisaged to implement the bottom–up dimension of the MTBF was not undertaken during 
FY2009 budget preparation. 
 
5.  The government reinitiated the MTBF reforms in preparing the FY2010 budget. A new 
fiscal framework for the top–down dimension MTBF is being developed for FY2010–FY2012. 
This will be fully integrated with the FY2010 budget, the latter being reflected as the first year of 
the MTBF. Pilot implementation of output-based budgeting is being implemented in DOH and 
DI&P. In line with this, a new budget call circular that reflects the budget ceilings for both current 
and development budgets was issued to the pilot departments in October 2008. Forms have 
been designed to implement output-based budgeting in the pilot departments. Training for 
drawing and disbursing officers of the spending units has been undertaken, and both the current 
and development budget are expected to be reviewed using the joint protocols developed under 
subprogram 1. The new MTBF will reflect the departmental resource envelopes. Adopting the 
MTBF process is the first step toward instituting a full-fledged performance budgeting system, 
since the process requires departments to specify goals in the form of measurable outputs and 
outcomes.  Through  MTBF,  the  government  wants  to  move  from  incremental  budgeting  to 
budgeting based on the actual cost of programs and projects. The government aims eventually 
to  organize  all  expenditure  by  means  of  MTBF  exercises,  including  local  government

36  Appendix 2 
 
expenditures. Implementing MTBF will help do away with the unwarranted bifurcation of the 
provincial budget.  
 
6.  Prevalence  of  supplementary  grants.  The  MTBF  is  designed  to  introduce  both 
accuracy  and  stability  in  the  budget.  Ideally, a  well-estimated  budget  should  minimize  the 
introduction  of  supplementary  budgets.  However,  the  system  in  Punjab  allows  retroactive 
approval of supplementary grants, by which means the demand for supplementary grants for 
the current fiscal year are approved at the end of the fiscal year, together with the next fiscal 
year's budget. Supplementary grants have been subject to political requests. As a result, they 
are quite prevalent, averaging around 21% of aggregate expenditures from FY2004 to FY2008 
(Table A3.2). To address this situation, the Finance Department has instituted a mid-year review 
of the FY2009 budget that includes insistence on justification for supplementary grants. In 
addition, pre-budget consultations with members of the provincial assembly were conducted in 
February 2009 in preparation for the FY2010 budget.

7.  Continued  weak  coordination  between  budgeting  and  planning.  The  dual 
budgeting system makes MTBF implementation challenging. It is important that mindsets in both 
the  Finance  Department  and  P&DD  change  toward  improving  coordination,  particularly  at 
operating  levels.  Operating  procedures  need  to  be  aligned  to  pursue  the  integrated 
implementation of the MTBF. While the budget call circular issued by the Finance Department 
prescribes  ceilings  for  current  and  development  budgets  with  its  corresponding  templates, 
P&DD  subsequently  issued  another  instruction  for  the  MTDF  with  its  own  ceilings  for 
departments. The issuance of dual instructions should be avoided in the future. Further, there is 
a  lack  of  coherence  between  the  budget  classification  systems  followed  by  the  Finance 
Department and the P&DD. No standards have been adopted to reclassify the scheme-based 
MTDF  classification  to  the  functional,  economic,  and  administrative  classifications  that  are 
consistent with the chart of accounts of the new accounting model. Transforming the current 
scheme-wise classification to a chart of account–consistent classification will add an extra layer 
in budget preparation for development expenditures. 
 
8.  Underutilized development expenditures (annual development program). Punjab's 
annual development program (ADP) for FY2009 is PRs160 billion, accounting for about 38% of 
the budget. While the throw-forward for the whole ADP has been kept at about 3 years, it varies 
by sector. In some sectors, such as irrigation, the throw-forward, particularly for new schemes, 
can extend to more than 20 years. There are no rules to ensure that unapproved schemes will 
be  approved  during  the  current  fiscal  year  and  a  large  share  of  new  schemes  remain 
unapproved throughout the fiscal year. During mid-year reviews of the ADP, funds are re-
appropriated from non-moving or slow-moving schemes to fast-moving ones at the discretion of

Appendix 2      37 
P&DD. There are no rules for prioritizing development schemes, whose inclusion has been 
partly driven by political requests. 
 
9.  Weak revenue mobilization. The lack of precision in the provincial budget largely 
reflects poor revenue forecasting. For example, federal government transfers account for about 
75%–80%  of  total  provincial  receipts.  Lower-than-expected  revenues  from  the  federal 
government translate into lower fiscal transfers accruing to the government. Likewise, there is 
much potential for improving own-source revenues. Both tax and nontax revenues have been 
significantly below budget estimates (Table A3.3). Taxation in Punjab is undertaken by two 
agencies, the Excise and Taxation Department (E&TD) and the Board of Revenue. The PRMP 
had earlier attempted to reform the stamp tax, urban immovable property tax (UIPT), and 
agricultural income tax but was constrained by the poor tax administration.

10.  Own-source revenue generation is hampered by weak tax administration capacity and 
the prevalence of leakage in the tax system. E&TD administers eight taxes, of which the UIPT

been undertaken since 2001, resulting in considerable undervaluing of property. Exemptions 
have significantly diluted the revenue potential of the UIPT. E&TD has indicated that about 50% 
of the tax base (1.8 million properties) is exempt, which amounts to PRs2.4 billion in foregone 
revenues.

11.  The  government  has  taken  steps  toward  reforming  the  property  tax  in  Punjab.  In 
December 2007, it adopted its 5-year medium-term framework for UIPT reforms. Among the key 
steps is the establishment of a review committee for the UIPT. The committee was notified in 
August 2008, and a report was prepared in October 2008 outlining the reform options on the

38  Appendix 2 
 
UIPT, including rationalizing exemptions. With World Bank support, a draft UIPT law has been 
prepared and is being review by the government.  
 
12.  E&TD is currently developing and populating its property database, which can be used 
for billing and assessment. As of February 2009, the database included 100,000 properties. An 
ongoing reform is linking the geographic information system—referred to as Iris and developed 
by the Urban Unit of P&DD—with the E&TD property database to improve the collection of the 
UIPT. Started in 2008, Iris aims to digitize 700,000 properties in Lahore and store them in a 
geographic  information  system  environment  where  they  can  be  matched  up  with  E&TD 
assessment and billing information.  
 
13.  The other tax that has good yield potential is the motor vehicle tax (MVT). E&TD has 
indicated that it has a fairly good motor vehicle registration database but that there are problems 
with the collection points. The MVT is paid to post offices and the National Bank of Pakistan (the 
bank). Payments through post offices are done manually without maintaining proper collection 
records. There is no online connection with the bank. Discussions for online connection have 
been initiated with the bank, but they have stalled and the latter has not shown an interest in 
pursuing this option. E&TD has suggested that collection could be done through private banks 
that can establish an online link with E&TD. On the professional tax, E&TD suggested that one 
way to improve collection is to introduce such electronic payments as credit cards and smart 
cards. 
 
14.  E&TD has raised issues about its weak capacity for tax collection. There is also scope 
for reforming the structure of E&TD to more clearly demarcate assessment, collection, audit, 
and  appeal.  Currently,  tax  assessment  and  collection  are  not  separated,  and  there  is  no 
effective tax audit or internal control. There is likewise scope for tax facilitation measures. One 
possible reform is to establish model E&TD collection offices that are taxpayer friendly.  
 
15.  The Board of Revenue collects five taxes, with the stamp duty and registration fee as 
the high-yielding ones. It has looked at possible administrative or process reforms for these 
taxes,  but  these  necessitate  legislative  measures  that  require  the  approval  of  the  federal 
parliament. In February 2007, the government approved the Board of Revenue Automation 
Project, amounting to PRs50 million, which aims to (i) improve the efficiency of work and 
maintenance of records in the Board of Revenue by automating systems and reengineering 
business processes and (ii) strengthen the capacity building of Board of Revenue staff to 
improve their efficiency. The project has not been implemented, however.   
 
B.  Management of Contingent Pension and GP Fund Liabilities 
 
16.  Background. The civil service retirement system has two main parts: the pension 
scheme and the General Provident Fund (GP Fund). In addition, civil servants are covered by 
the  benevolent  fund  scheme  and  a  group  insurance  policy.  This  analysis  covers  only  the 
pension and GP Fund schemes.  
 
17.  The  pension  scheme  is  non-contributory  and  pay-as-you-go  with  defined  benefits. 
Pensions are paid from the budget and do not require employee contributions. So far, the 
budget covers the full cost of pensions. The benefit is determined by a formula based on the 
final  monthly  basic  salary  times  2.33%  for  each  year  of  service  completed.  The  normal 
retirement age is 60, subject to having completed 10 years of service. For those who fail to meet 
the  minimum  requirement,  a  gratuity  is  paid.  A  maximum  of  30  years  of  service  can  be 
computed to reach a maximum pension benefit equal to 70% of the basic wage. Civil servants

Appendix 2      39 
can retire voluntarily after 25 years of service. Up to 35% of the pension benefit can be taken as 
a lump sum. The remainder is paid as an annuity until death. Upon the death of a recipient, a 
survivor’s benefit equal to half the pension is paid. Disability benefits are also provided. The 
annuity is not indexed but rather increased on a discretionary basis.  
 
18.  The GP Fund is a contributory, notionally funded, defined contribution scheme. Monthly 
contributions, ranging between 3% and 8% of basic pay, are deducted from the civil servants' 
monthly pay. To date, employee contributions are not kept separately in a fund but included in 
the budget. Interest rates are annually declared by the federal Ministry of Finance and have 
averaged 15% annually over the past 35 years, well above market rates and substantially 
increasing the final benefit payment. Civil servants can borrow from their GP Fund for specific 
purposes up to the age of 50. After this age, civil servants can borrow up to 60% of the balance 
without having to give a reason or pay back the advance. After age 55, an advance of 80% of 
the balance can be made. The remaining balance is paid out as a lump sum at the age of 60. 
 
19.  Rising  pension  and  GP  Fund  costs  and  liabilities.  The  actuarial  assessment, 
commissioned under the first subprogram, estimated the accrued pension liability at PRs425 
billion as of 30 June 2007, of which 70% pertains to current civil servants and the remainder to 
pensioners. Annual pension expenditure was projected to increase rapidly from PRs15.1 billion 
in FY2009 to PRs63.5 billion in FY2024, a growth of 10% each year over the next 15 years. A 
preliminary update of pension liability shows that the accrued pension liability grew to PRs515 
billion as of 30 June 2008. The increase in liability arises mainly from significantly higher salary 
increases  (20%)  and  pension  indexation  (20%)  announced  in  the  2009  budget  speech, 
compared to the respective 9% and 6% assumed in the actuarial assessment.    
 
20.  In September 2007, the government passed the Pension Fund Act and prepared a note 
providing a funding strategy up to 2030 for the Punjab Pension Fund. The government planned 
to transfer PRs100 billion ($1.7 billion) to the Punjab Pension Fund and the General Provident 
Investment Fund by FY2016. After the initial period, annual funding would be linked to the 
payroll expenditure of the government. The capitalization would allow the government to cover 
approximately 30% of the pension expenditures from FY2016-FY2030. Under subprogram 1, 
the government and ADB agreed on the funding strategy outlined below. 
 
21.  So far, the government has put aside in FY2009 and FY 2010, in a bank account 
separate from the government budget, PRs12 billion, lower than the PRs20 billion originally 
envisaged.  The  change  in  economic  climate  and  the  reduced  loan  size  and  delayed 
disbursement for subprogram 2 are the main reasons for slower-than-planned capitalization. 
Financing the funding strategy for pensions has to compete with more urgent spending on 
security, subsidies, and social safety nets, as well as the continued need to repay expensive 
domestic debts. At the same time, the pace and volume of ADB budget support is much lower 
than projected in 2007. A new funding strategy is prepared based on an updated actuarial 
valuation. Over time, the strategy will need to be adapted to changing circumstances. 
 
22.  In  2007,  the  government  adopted  the  Punjab  Pension  Fund  Act  and  created  an 
investment fund into which it would transfer monies to finance part of the future civil service 
pension payments. International best practice requires a set of internal statutes and external 
regulations  to  ensure  that  the  investment  fund  is  managed  in  the  best  interests  of  the 
beneficiaries. Substantial progress has been made since the creation of the Punjab Pension 
Fund. A management committee has been established. Staff for the investment unit, including 
the general manager, have been hired from the private sector. A trustee, legal advisor, and

40  Appendix 2 
 
external auditor have been appointed. A short-term investment strategy has been developed 
based on the new financing strategy and in line with the investment policy. 
 
23.  The  Punjab  General  Provident  Investment  Fund  (GPIF)  Act  was  enacted  by  the 
provincial assembly on 2 July 2009, after which the management committee notified the new 
funds  regulations.  Both  the  Punjab  Pension  Fund  account  and  the  GPIF  account  will  be 
managed by a single investment unit. This will require some changes in the oversight board and 
in the investment unit of the Punjab Pension Fund. Additional reforms are required in the 
management committee to strengthen oversight.  
 
24.  It is necessary to look at the long-term costs on an accrual basis to assess the solvency 
and long-term sustainability of the pension and GP Fund schemes. Initial estimates based on 
the actuarial assessment show that the pension and GP Fund costs currently reported are 
substantially lower than the accrued value. 
 
25.  Poor data- and record-keeping. The information currently available is of insufficient 
quality to allow decisions ensuring adequate management of the pension scheme and GP Fund, 
much less to produce reliable actuarial estimates. The available data is insufficient for reliable 
analysis of current and future costs. The quality of planning and management decisions suffers 
as they are made on inaccurate, incomplete, and inadequate information. No pension scheme 
can operate optimally without an adequate, reliable, and current database. All pension and GP 
Fund records were stored manually in ledger books, which are difficult to access. The Project to 
Implement Financial Reporting and Accounting (PIFRA) was introduced to computerize the 
whole accounting and auditing system of the country, including automating the employee payroll, 
pension, and GP Fund record-keeping system. The main challenge is to populate the database 
with accurate and complete data, especially the historic GP Fund data that covers the monthly 
contributions of all civil servants starting from the date of appointment. A pilot project has been 
initiated to test alternative methods of collecting, verifying, and entering accurate and complete 
data in the most efficient and cost-effective way.  
 
C.  Civil Service Reform 
 
26.  An efficient, accountable, and enabling civil service is the backbone of a country’s 
institutional architecture. With Punjab's 40 departments, 35 districts, and hundreds of municipal 
administrations, and, most importantly, 86 million people, the civil service machinery of the 
government must be well structured, have efficient business processes, and be geared toward 
the effective delivery of public services. The need to reform the civil service has been felt both 
nationally and provincially. The most prominent reforms at the federal level were introduced in 
1973 and 2001. Despite various reform attempts, the common perception is that the system 
remains similar to that inherited from Pakistan’s colonial past. A survey by the Pakistan Institute 
of Development Economics indicates widespread negative perceptions and general discontent 
about public services and disillusionment among civil servants. The civil service system suffers 
many problems, some of the most crucial of which are summarized below.  
  
1.  Key Issues 
a.  Overstretched Government Functions 
27.  Punjab needs productive employment to generate income for its people. It also needs 
more and better social and infrastructure services. Yet per capita development expenditure in 
Punjab is only about $16 per year. The constraints on the government’s financial and human

Appendix 2      41 
resources mean that attracting private sector participation in the economy is essential. Further, 
there is increasing empirical evidence that the private sector is more suited to and efficient in 
carrying out economic activities. In recent years, there have been increasing successful models 
for private sector participation in infrastructure and social services, a domain that is traditionally 
monopolized by the public sector. Increased private sector participation, however, does not 
mean  that  the  government  will  abdicate  or  dilute  its  responsibilities;  rather,  these  can 
increasingly be more strategic and targeted. The government will remain the referee to make 
and apply the rules and regulations to ensure a level playing field and quality of services. 
 
28.  Civil service reform (CSR) needs to deal with the division of responsibilities between 
the private and public sectors. Pakistan has carried out privatization and deregulation over the 
past  2  decades  and  benefited  from  a  more  dynamic  private  sector.  The  process  remains 
incomplete, however. The government owns 123 autonomous bodies, many of which engage in 
commercial  activities  at  a  loss.  In  addition  to  autonomous  bodies,  some  government 
departments  undertake  economic  activities,  such  as  the  printing  press  in  the  Industries 
Department.  
 
29.  The  PGEIP  supports  in-depth  reforms  in  E&TD  and  the  Livestock  and  Dairy 
Department.  A  functional  review  is  especially important  for  L&DD.  In  addition  to  providing 
extensive services, the department undertakes the production of animal feed and vaccines. It 
owns more than 2,000 hectares of land and 20 farms whose productivity is low. Livestock 
contributes over 40% of total agricultural outputs. Farmers derive 40% of their income from 
livestock, and 35 million rural people are engaged in raising livestock. Despite its importance, 
the sector encounters many problems. Fodder and feed resources are inadequate, and the 
productivity of fodder is low because of poor research and extension support. Animal health 
cover and artificial insemination are still far from satisfactory. The standardization of livestock 
products is also weak. Only 3% of milk is processed. A functional review of L&DD needs to 
explore how the private sector can play a larger role in supporting dairy industry development. 
L&DD has already started work along these lines.   
 
b.  Outdated Business Process 
30.  Inefficient processes absorb many resources for unproductive activities. Government 
procedures  in  Punjab  are  generally  considered  lengthy  and  cumbersome.  The  advent  of 
information technology provides great scope for business process reengineering to improve the 
efficiency and responsiveness of the government. In Punjab, the use of information technology 
is limited in the public sector despite a vibrant private information technology sector. The switch 
from manual to automated processes is slow and will require a new skills mix and training for 
civil servants. The PGEIP supports the automation of processes in a number of organizations, 
such as E&TD, L&DD, Punjab Public Service Commission, and Management and Professional 
Department.  Business  process  reengineering  supported  by  information  technology  will 
eventually be expanded to the whole government.  
 
c.  Obsolete Human Resource Management System 
31.  The human resource management system in Punjab suffers from many problems. The 
Punjab Public Service Commission (PPSC) recruits public servants for the basic pay scale2 17 
                                                 
2 The civil service of Pakistan is structured across 22 basic pay scales (BPS). With some exceptions, the government 
officers of BPS 17 and higher are categorized as gazetted officers and assigned middle to senior level managerial 
responsibilities such as heads of sections, departments, field offices and drawing and disbursing officers. Civil 
servants below BPS 17 generally work as support staff.

42  Appendix 2 
 
and above. Structural, capacity, and procedural constraints cause long delays in recruitment, up 
to 1 year in some cases. A large proportion of civil servants do not have job descriptions. The 
annual confidential report, instead of being a performance evaluation record, is commonly 
regarded as a compliance task. Moreover, performance evaluations play a limited role in career 
progression in a system in which promotions are largely based on seniority. There is substantial 
evidence that the real compensation gap between public and private salaries and conditions has 
steadily widened. In addition, the wage structure is not linked to performance and does not 
provide adequate incentives for good performance. The provincial government has no control 
over civil service salary scales, which are set by the federal government. The government can, 
however, create contract positions outside the cadre scales or pay additional allowances for 
specific positions. For example, project or program management units have been used as a 
device to create specific positions attracting higher rewards. However, the creation of islands of 
excellence has caused uneasiness among civil servants. Tenure is short, and transfers are 
often made within a year, eroding performance. Often, incumbents barely have time to settle 
into a new job before they are moved on. Capacity constraints in the public sector are acute, 
and training is not valued.  
  
2.  Punjab's Efforts in Civil Service Reform    
32.  The root causes of most civil service problems can be traced to structural, procedural, 
and motivational deficiencies in the overall system of governance. Any attempts to treat the 
symptoms in an isolated manner without tackling the root causes will not be effective. The 
reform package thus must be comprehensive, with a clear blueprint, but be introduced in a 
properly phased and sequenced manner. Fully aware of the challenges it faces in attempting 
such reforms, the government carried out widespread consensus building on CSR with private 
and public sector stakeholders. It has also taken steps to push forward reforms. A high-powered 
CSR Task Force has been set up. A CSR policy has been approved by the cabinet to enable 
and guide CSR. Two departments, E&TD and L&DD, have been selected by the Government of 
Punjab  to  undertake  fully  fledged  functional  reviews,  business  process  reengineering,  and 
human resource reforms. Supported by the Program, PPSC has moved away from an inefficient 
procedures of interviewing all candidates to only the shortlisted candidates. Other efforts of 
business process reengineering in PPSC is underway and expected to significantly improve 
efficiency in recruitment. The government has strengthened its training capability to upgrade the 
skills of provincial employees. The government has started to clearly benchmark civil service 
performance indicators, initially in E&TD, L&DD, and PPSC. The comparison of performance 
before and after will be essential for evaluating the impact of reforms, as well as for encouraging 
departments to improve performance and service delivery.  
 
D.  Support Dynamic Private Sector–Led Growth 
 
33.  Background. Punjab's private sector plays an important role in Pakistan. About 70% of 
manufacturing  establishments  are  located  in  Punjab.  Punjab  produces  the  bulk  of  most 
industrial outputs: 77% of sugar, 70% of fertilizer, 69% of cotton yarn, 96% of paper and 
paperboard, and 44% of cement. The elasticity of outputs with respect to employment for most 
industries is above 1, indicating that a 1% increase in outputs leads to an increase of more than 
1% in employment. The textiles sector is the largest, with the highest rate of labor absorption, 
employing 56% of the industrial labor force. The bulk of Punjab's firms employ fewer than 10 
workers.    The  economy  of  Punjab  is  undergoing  structural  transformation  away  from  its 
traditional reliance on agriculture toward increased dependence on manufacturing and services. 
The  share  of  agriculture  declined  from  31%  in  FY1991  to  21%  in  FY2006,  while  that  of 
manufacturing increased from 13% to 20% and of services from 49% to 53%. Despite the

Appendix 2      43 
changes, 44% of Punjab’s labor force is employed in agriculture However, strong growth in 
manufacturing  and  services  will  be  crucial  to  generating  future  productive  employment 
opportunities.   
 
34.  Punjab's business climate is constrained by regulatory hurdles, low human capital 
capacity,  and  poor  infrastructure,  among  other  factors.  Consequently,  the  private  sector 
operates mostly informally. A study by the World Bank3 pointed out that improvements in the 
investment climate (such as a reduction in power outages and in management time spent 
dealing with regulations, etc.) could sharply increase the productivity of firms. Some of the 
results could be quite spectacular. The report estimated that if the quality of the investment 
environment in Pakistan were to match that of Shanghai, the productivity of Pakistan's textile 
firms operating in Karachi would improve on average by 81%, the rate of return to capital by 
36%, and wages by 23%. Some key business climate issues are discussed below.  
 
1.  Removing Infrastructure Bottlenecks through Public–Private Partnership  
 
35.  Weak physical infrastructure has been a major factor hindering the competitiveness 
and performance of manufacturing in Pakistan. The expensive and unreliable electricity supply 
poses heavy costs on business. To minimize downtime caused by problems in power supply, 
firms are often forced to use their own generators. The use of generators is estimated to tie up 
to about 12% of firms' fixed capital assets. The unsatisfactory state of the transportation network 
has imposed enormous costs on the economy: according to a recent estimate, inefficiency in 
transport alone costs the economy of Pakistan PRs320 billion a year, and a large share of this 
cost is in Punjab. The lack of repair and maintenance of existing roads has caused rapid 
deterioration of the road network. It is estimated that 90% of the provincial road network is rated 
as fair to poor. Poor urban infrastructure and service delivery—in water supply and sanitation, 
urban transport, and solid waste management—impairs the competitiveness of firms, affects the 
environment and health, and constrains investment growth.   
  
36.  Developing  infrastructure  requires  large  capital  investment.  While  Pakistan's  total 
development expenditure budget was only $6 billion in FY2009, the estimated need for annual 
infrastructure investment is $20 billion, and a large share of this is in Punjab. In recent years, 
public–private partnership (PPP) has emerged as a major instrument for financing and providing 
public services, gradually replacing the traditional public sector modality. Developed countries 
such as Canada and Singapore require that large public investment projects go through a 
filtering process and be carried out using PPP unless there are compelling reasons not to do so.   
 
37.  In view of the government's limited resources, it has introduced several partnership 
models, including developing industrial estates, developing the livestock and dairy industry, 
encouraging  the  expansion  and  development  of  housing,  and  promoting  skill  development 
through the Technical Education and Vocational Training Authority. However, mainstreaming 
PPP  requires  enabling  institutional,  legal,  and  financial  frameworks.  It  also  requires  that 
government  departments  have  adequate  skills  to design  and  implement  PPP.  Institutional, 
policy,  and  legal  frameworks  in  Punjab  are  not  well  developed.  There  are  acute  capacity 
constraints, with very little locally available experience in developing PPP projects. The lack of 
successful PPP projects makes it difficult to judge the risks involved.      
 
                                                 
3  World Bank. 2006. Pakistan: Growth and Export Competitiveness. Washington DC.

44  Appendix 2 
 
38.  The  government  has  made  substantial  progress  toward  creating  an  enabling 
environment for PPP.4 A PPP Cell has been notified. A PPP framework has been developed to 
outline a road map for developing PPP. A PPP policy has been approved by the Cabinet, 
articulating the government's intention to adopt PPP as a key modality for infrastructure and 
social service delivery. A PPP law has been prepared and discussed with stakeholders, and 
was submitted to the provincial assembly. A series of training workshops have been held for key 
line  departments.  Efforts  have  been  made  to  support  PPP  project  development.  Project 
development facility (PDF) guidelines were approved by the provincial cabinet, and PDF was 
capitalized with a fund of about $1 million. A list of potentially bankable projects has been 
developed,  and  work  on  selected  projects  has  started.  The  PGEIP  will  support  Punjab’s 
mainstreaming of PPP with at least 20% of infrastructure and social services projects delivered 
through PPP in a decade, up from a current level that is negligible.  
 
2.  Improving Regulatory Frameworks.  
 
39.  Most regulations remain within the purview of federal government. Overregulation is 
prevalent, with nearly 60 separate government regulations and laws being applied to small and 
medium-sized firms. One particular issue in Pakistan is the lack of review and updating of 
regulations. Many regulations were developed in the colonial era and continue on the books 
despite  long  since  outliving  their  usefulness.  Over  time,  new  and  sometimes  conflicting 
regulations have been developed, creating a complex web. Proper institutional mechanisms 
need to be set up to review and update regulations and to evaluate the cost and benefits of new 
regulations. While these efforts need to be spearheaded by the federal government, provincial 
governments can make a positive contribution by actively engaging in dialogue with it and 
simplifying regulations that fall within their mandate.  
 
40.  Supported by the World Bank, Punjab is undertaking its first doing business survey. 
Preliminary results indicate that compliance costs are considered high by most firms. The final 
results will feed into the identification and addressing of regulatory barriers. The PGEIP will 
support Punjab's efforts to simplify existing regulations and undertake regulatory impact analysis 
for new regulations.  
 
E.  Adopt Results-Based Management 
 
41.  The government has identified income growth and improved social services as its twin 
development  objectives.  Punjab’s  Vision  2020  projects  Punjab  as  a  reasonably  well-off, 
educated, and healthy society by 2020, envisaging a doubling of per capita income to $2,000 in 
the  same  period.  The  government  wants  to  adopt  modern  public  sector  management 
techniques  to  achieve  this  vision  and  is  in  the  process  of  introducing  a  results-based 
management (RBM) framework linking development objectives, outcomes, outputs, systems, 
and resources to guide reforms and monitor the progress of the province in realizing its vision.   
 
42.  RBM  is  a  public  sector  management  philosophy  and  approach  that  focuses  on 
achieving goals and objectives through strategic planning; systematic implementation; effective 
resource use; and performance monitoring, measurement, reporting, and evaluation to improve 
result delivery. It has been successfully implemented by many countries, most notably Malaysia 
and Canada. Punjab has started to introduce the result framework and desires to benefit from 
                                                 
4  ADB. 2007. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Program 
Cluster, Loan for Subprogram 1, Technical Assistance Loan, and Technical Assistance Grants for the Islamic 
Republic of Pakistan for the Punjab Government Efficiency Improvement Program. Manila (Loan 2386-PAK).

Appendix 2      45 
the experience of these countries. RBM in Punjab aims to serve as an important tool to help 
legislators, executives, people, and development agencies monitor and evaluate how well the 
government is performing and achieving outcomes. The key sectors include education, health, 
water supply and sanitation, irrigation and power, transport, livestock and dairy, taxation, and 
private sector development. RBM pays particular attention to achieving positive gender results.  
 
43.  Punjab's RBM framework focuses on achieving development goals through clearly 
identified development targets. While it stresses the importance of identifying and tracking 
development  indicators,  it  pays  special  attention  to  improving  the  efficiency  of  resource 
management. In this regard, it is critical to put in place sound public financial management, 
human  resource  management,  efficient  business  processes  supported  by  information 
technology, and monitoring and evaluation systems. There are great needs for optimizing the 
function of government and enabling greater private sector participation in economic activities 
and  delivering  infrastructure  and  social  services.  These  form  the  foundation  for  delivering 
development results. Over time, the RBM framework will support a development agenda that 
shifts  emphasis  from  inputs  and  activities  to  greater  accountability  for  results,  and  it  will 
transform  public  sector  management  in  Punjab  from  rigid  micro  management  to  greater 
accountability for development results, combined with flexibility and autonomy for management.

Appendix 8  73
SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY   
Country/Program Title: Pakistan/Punjab Government Efficiency Improvement Program 
Lending/Financing  Department/  Central and West Asia Department 
Policy-Based 
Modality:  Division:  Financial Sector, Public Management and Trade Division 
I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
In January 2009, the Government of Pakistan released its second National Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP-
II). It covers a 3-year period from fiscal year (FY) 2009 to FY2011. PRSP-II builds upon nine pillars: (i) macroeconomic 
stability and real sector growth, (ii) protecting the poor and the vulnerable, (iii) increasing productivity and value 
addition in agriculture, (iv) an integrated energy development program, (v) making industry internationally competitive, 
(vi) human development for the 21st century, (vii) removing bottlenecks through public–private partnership (PPP), 
(viii) capital and finance for development, and (ix) governance for a just and fair system. The Punjab Government 
Efficiency Improvement Program (PGEIP) echoes the strategic thrust of PRSP-II, focusing on the efficient and effective 
delivery  of  public  services.  Common  areas  between  the  federal  and  provincial  development  strategies  include 
(i) strengthening tax administration to mobilize additional resources for development; (ii) improving accountability and 
financial management by developing a medium-term budgetary framework (MBTF); (iii) civil service reform toward a 
competent, effective, and neutral civil service; and (iv) the promotion of PPP to increase demand for income-generating 
employment and the provision of key services and to overcome constraints on the government's financial and human 
resources. 
 
Provincial financial resource management reform is a major strategic area in ADB's Country Partnership Strategy 
2009–2013, aiming to reduce market distortions and institutional bottlenecks, improve public financial and human 
resource management, develop the private sector, and promote structural transformation. The other main strategic 
areas are energy, infrastructure and urban services. Building on the first generation reforms included in the public 
resource management programs (PRMPs) and the devolved social services programs, new assistance under the 
Country  Partnership  Strategy  is  focused  on  improving  medium-term  budgetary  frameworks,  strengthening  the 
provincial government's capacity to plan and manage expenditure allocations, strengthening tax administration skills, 
and creating an enabling business and regulatory environment that reduces the cost of doing business. 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                    Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
1.  Key Issues  
Punjab experienced strong annual growth of 7%–8% between FY2003 and FY2008, allowing significant poverty 
reduction. Federal poverty estimates based on the 2005/06 Pakistan Socioeconomic Living Standard Measurement 
Surveya indicated a decline in the number of people living below the poverty lineb from 34.5% of the population in 
FY2000/01 to 22.3% in FY2005/06, a decline of 12.2%. While the magnitude of the decline is disputed, the trend is 
widely accepted. The key issue is whether the trend can be sustained and the pace of poverty reduction is fast enough. 
Even with a poverty level of 22.3%, roughly 35 million people would still be living below the poverty line. This is higher 
than the number of poor in Pakistan in FY1996/97. Further, rural poverty is substantially more prevalent than in urban 
areas. In FY2004/05, the overall poverty incidence in Punjab was 29.7%, with the 20.6% urban area rate much lower 
than the 33.9% rural rate. 
 
The lack of new poverty data after FY2005/06 precludes an update of the poverty situation, but it is probable that 
poverty started increasing again in FY2008/09 with high domestic inflation caused by high food and energy prices. The 
Punjab Multiple Indicators Cluster Survey indicates that the impact of food price increases on poverty is substantially 
greater than the impact of energy price increases. A 20% increase in food prices would lead to an 8% increase in the 
poverty head count, from 36% to 44%, with the harmful impact of food price shocks falling disproportionately on the 
rural poor.  
2. Design Features 
Although the PGEIP is categorized as a general intervention, it has a pro-poor focus with an increased expenditure on 
social safety nets. In the face of recent dramatic food shocks, the government decided to provide food security to poor 
households through (i) the Punjab Food Support Scheme, (ii) the Sasti Roti Scheme, (iii) the Free Medicine Initiative, 
(iv) support for deserving students, and (v) the Green Tractors Scheme. The Punjab Food Support Scheme provides 
cash  transfers  of  PRs1,000  per  month  to  1.8  million  poor  families.  The  cost  of  the  scheme  is  estimated  at 
PRs10.8 billion for FY2009. Sasti Roti subsidizes tandoors to provide roti to the poor at a rate of Prs2 per roti. The 
Finance Department indicated that PRs6.1 billion would be spent under the scheme in FY2009. The Free Medicine 
Initiative is expected to cost PRs1.8 billion in FY2010. Support for deserving students is expected to cost PRs3 billion, 
and the Green Tractor Scheme PRs2 billion. The PGEIP supports pro-poor expenditure by improving public resource 
management and creating fiscal space.

74  Appendix 8   
 
A.  Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending  
 
1.  Discuss the impact channels of the policy reform(s) to the country and major groups affected. 
 
The PGEIP will provide significant benefits in general and directed benefits for the poor in particular.  
 
(i)  First, it will help the government to improve public financial management by strengthening the revenue system, as 
well as improving spending efficiency.  
(ii)  Second, the PGEIP will help the government to improve contingent liability management by capitalizing the 
Punjab Pension Fund and the General Provident Investment Fund and by instilling sound fiduciary practices in 
fund management, as well as by improving the record-keeping and administration of both schemes. 
(iii)  Third, the PGEIP will contribute to enhancing civil service management by improving the functions, business 
processes, and human resource management of the civil service and by linking performance with service delivery 
indicators. 
(iv)  Fourth, the PGEIP will enable the private sector by promoting PPP for infrastructure and social service delivery 
and improving the regulatory environment. 
 
2.  Discuss the impact of the policy reform(s) on vulnerable groups and ways to address it/them (refer to social 
analysis). 
 
The government faces multiple challenges. Poverty is high, and social indicators are low. Infrastructure and productive 
employment opportunities are lacking. At the same time the government faces fiscal constraints resulting in annual 
budget deficits. The PGEIP will assist the government in strengthening both the provincial revenue systems and 
expenditure  management,  including  improved  contingent  liability  management  needed  for  improved  spending 
efficiency, allowing for a larger share of development expenditure, which in turn supports the provision of infrastructure 
and social services for social development and economic growth. The reform of the civil service will eventually lead to a 
competent, effective, and neutral civil service that will provide better services to the public for some core public 
services. It will encourage greater private sector participation. The private sector is in general a more efficient creator of 
jobs. As such, it can contribute to employment generation and at the same time create more fiscal space by taking 
pressure off the government budget.   
 
3.  Discuss how the policy reform(s) contribute(s) to poverty reduction, pro-poor growth, and the MDGs. 
 
The challenge of poverty alleviation remains huge. Pakistan, being a signatory to the Millennium Development Goals 
(MDGs), is committed to achieving the MDG target for poverty by halving the incidence of poverty between 1990 and 
2015, from an estimated 26% in 1990 to 13%. With the latest poverty estimates from FY2005/06 at 22.3%, there is a 
long way to go. The poverty problem cannot be eliminated immediately and will require sustained efforts. The 
continued and consistent pursuit of pro-poor growth policies—along with accompanying investments; a focus on 
effective investment spending; and the forging of long-term partnerships with the private sector, civil society, and 
development institutions—will be key to ensuring the long-term success of the government’s poverty reduction strategy 
and programs.    
II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis 
The 2007 Punjab Economic Survey found 20% of the provincial population to be poor, with a higher concentration of 
poor in the rural areas (44%). This means roughly 18 million people in Punjab live under the poverty line, and 
vulnerability is high. Social indicators are poor in Punjab. Malnutrition is high, with one third of children under 5 being 
underweight, which poses a serious public health problem. The infant mortality rate and the maternal mortality rate are 
double the MDG targets. The literacy rate for children 10 years of age is 56% in Punjab, and the dropout rate is 30%. 
Only half of the population is served by piped water systems and a covered sewerage system. The lack of human 
development is a hindrance for social and economic progress. Further. Punjab faces large infrastructure deficits that 
hamper economic growth. The lack of productive employment opportunities is another serious problem. The PGEIP 
fully recognizes and confronts the institutional roots of these problems.  
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1.  Provide a summary of the consultation and participation process during the project preparation. 
 
The design of the PGEIP is the result of stakeholder consultations at all levels of government and with civil society. The 
consensus-building strategy for the second subprogram of the PGEIP is in line with that used for the PRMP, which was 
the result of a policy dialogue that began in 2002 and continues today.  
 
2.  What level of consultation and participation (C&P) is envisaged during the project implementation and monitoring?

Appendix 8  75
  Information sharing          Consultation         Collaborative decision making       Empowerment 
 
3.  Was a C&P plan prepared?    Yes      No  
If a C&P plan was prepared, describe key features and resources provided to implement the plan (including budget, 
consultant input, etc.). If no, explain why.  
The PGEIP entails a continuous policy dialogue with all key stakeholders in the province. In addition, the cluster 
approach with regular dialogue will continue to ensure that the reforms stay broadly on track. 
C.   Gender and Development 
Key Issues. Gender inequality continues to be a major problem in Punjab. The literacy rate for females is still 
substantially lower than for males. Large gender disparities persist across the urban and rural areas but tend to be 
higher in rural areas. Limited access to income-generating opportunities—together with a range of lifecycle risks 
related to malnutrition, school non-attendance, marriage and dowry, pregnancy, child birth, and widowhood—have left 
women considerably more vulnerable to poverty than men, resulting in the increasing feminization of poverty.         
 
Key  Actions.  ADB  has  supported  gender  reforms  in  Pakistan.  Among  the  targeted  programs  for  gender 
mainstreaming in Pakistan, ADB supported the Government of Pakistan in developing a national gender reform action 
plan (GRAP) under the Decentralization Support Program, which was later approved by the national assembly, and 
provincial GRAPs that were approved by provincial assemblies and/or cabinets. Building upon past efforts, subprogram 
2 of the PGEIP has attempted to mainstream gender reforms and support gender equity in Punjab.   
 
As part of the PGEIP, the government has increased its efforts to promote gender equity. Two pre-budget seminars 
were conducted to increase awareness of gender-sensitive budgeting in FY2010. Resource allocation for GRAP 
implementation has more than doubled, from PRs70 million in FY2008 to  PRs148 million in FY2010. Gender 
mainstreaming units have been established in seven key departments. Gender support units have been established in 
27 districts. As part of subprogram 2, the gender support units conducted a review of 179 project documents, and 
these were subsequently revised to reflect a more gender-balanced approach. The annual development program for 
the health and education sectors has seen a clear focus on bridging the gap in services and infrastructure available for 
males and females. The government prepared gendered budget statements for the districts of Rajanpur and Gujrat and 
for the provincial government as a whole to gauge whether public investment is gender sensitive and balanced. The 
findings were incorporated into the gender section of the budget call circular for FY2010. All these efforts have 
contributed to gender-sensitive budgeting and planning.  
 
The government has established the Directorate of Women’s Development to be responsible for carrying out GRAP 
activities. The PGEIP supports gender-focused capacity building and the conduct of a series of workshops on gender-
equity sensitization in Punjab. Over time, gender equity will be a regular training topic in the curriculum of MPDD.   
 
The livestock and dairy sector contributes around 11% of provincial gross domestic product and employs 30 million 
people, largely in rural Pakistan. More importantly, over 90% of fresh milk consumed in Pakistan is from smallholder 
domestic production, which is managed mainly by women. Budget allocation for livestock and dairy more than doubled 
to PRs1,640 million in FY2010 from PRs806 million in FY2009. The initiatives will specifically augment the earning 
power of women and facilitate their empowerment in general.   
 
In addition to this direct assistance on gender equity, the PGEIP will support gender equity though increased fiscal 
space and fiscal discipline. The civil service reforms will improve service delivery and make government more 
responsive  to  citizen’s  needs,  especially  women  and  other  disadvantaged  groups.  The  PGEIP  is  introducing 
benchmarking and in-depth functional review, business process reengineering, and human resource management 
reforms in L&DD, which will have a positive impact on woman's earning power. The bridging of underfunding in the 
health sector will benefit women and children's health. PGEIP reforms, coupled with government interventions for pro-
poor expenditure and gender mainstreaming, will improve expenditure efficiency and sustain funding for social services 
that will particularly benefit women and other vulnerable groups. 
2.  Key Actions. Measures included in the design to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment—access 
to and use of relevant services, resources, assets, or opportunities and participation in decision-making process: 
   Gender plan          Other actions/measures         No action/measure 
 
Gender initiatives are included in three out of five core policy areas: public financial management, civil service reforms, 
and results-based management. Key actions are reflected in the policy matrix. In addition, a gender action plan for 
PGEIP subprogram 2 is included in the main text of the report and recommendation of the President.
